title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as CL 329RW 1, CPLT 389W 1, and WGS 385W 2) (Complete Topic - Tragic Heroines: Writing Women Across the Centuries) (This seminar will examine the role that women have played in the process of writing tragedy and how they have come to be viewed as the bearers of tragic pathos from classical antiquity to the Renaissance. The classical tragic figure could be either male or female, but the Renaissance ushers in new gender roles and modes of viewing that significantly alter this paradigm. In this class, we will explore the causes and effects of female subjectivity, agency, and sexuality beginning with Sophocles Antigone in 441 BCE and until the publication of Valeria Maini's lesbian-centered heroine, Celinda, published in 1611 CE. We will also focus on numerous theoretical texts that deal with the aesthetics of tragedy, all authored by men, to see how tragedy became a vehicle to challenge and question prevailing civic structures through the gendered lens of writing the tragic, female experience. Texts to be read may include a selection: Sophocles - Antigone Euripides - Alcestis Euripedes - Medea Seneca -Thyestes Gian Giorgio Trissino - Sofonisba Giambattista Giraldi Cinzio - Orbecche Sperone Speroni - Canace Torquato Tasso - Aminta and Re Torrismondo Aristotle - Poetics Horace - Ars Poetica Salvatore Di Maria - The Italian Tragedy in the Renaissance Freud - The Interpretation of Dreams and Beyond the Pleasure Principle Lacan - Seminar VII: The Ethics of Psychoanalysis)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 270 1 and MESAS 275 1) Course description: This course offers a general overview of the history of Jews and Judaism, beginning with the Biblical period and ending with modern times. Class notes: In this introductory level course we will consider major historical, cultural, legal, intellectual, and social developments among Jews from antiquity through the twentieth century. No previous knowledge is required. The course will explore how the Jews have defined themselves socially and politically in a number of historical and geographical settings, how Jewish theology and religious practice have been shaped and transformed, and how Jews have interacted with and responded to the societies in which they have lived. The class is arranged to comprehend broad themes rather than strict chronology and to engage both older and very recent scholarship. Focus on a rich variety of primary texts and images, including mosaics, poems, prayers, polemics, and personal letters will allow students to develop their skills at hands-on historical analysis. There will be several opportunities to visit collections of rare historic artifacts.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 358R 1 and ANT 385 9) (Complete Topic: Ethnography, Sacred Ethics and Assisted Reproductive Technologies) (How do different societies and religious communities understand the ethics of creating or terminating life through technology? What is distinctive about different kinds of religious bioethics (Catholic, Jewish, Muslim, etc.)? Does the diversity of religious bioethics have something special to teach bioethics in general? This course will investigate religious and cultural diversity of bioethics through ethnography, public policy and theology. We will consider technologies such as surrogacy, IVF, cloning, and abortion. Students will apply their moral reasoning to real world cases. Bring dinner with you to class!)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as GER 375 1, HIST 396 4, CPLT 389 4) At the beginning of the 20th century, fascism emerged as a new political phenomenon shaping the realities of Germany but also of other European countries, including Italy and Spain, while fostering strong movements across many others. This course examines how predominantly German-Jewish artists, writers, and scholars, through various media such as film, short stories, essays, and drama, sought to understand and depict the rise of fascism. We will explore these works alongside readings from right-wing authors. Our focus will be on the methods used to explain the emergence of reactionary ideologies, mass popular support, and authoritarian regimes. Key concepts and theoretical frameworks will guide our analysis of the political dynamics of the early 20th century. In addition, we will draw comparisons to contemporary analyses of right-wing movements in Europe and the US, questioning whether these earlier approaches remain relevant or if we are witnessing the rise of new, distinct forms of right-wing politics today.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: What is the role of the poet in society? Truth-teller, seducer, agitator, subversive? Prophet, memory-keeper, wordsmith of love? A freak who makes language go haywire? A genius who turns citizens into thriving humans? In this class, we'll dive headlong into this question, reading lots of poetry and lots of manifestos, vision-statements, and other poetry-should-do-type documents which poets wrote to orient their quest. We'll explore many trajectories together: poetry about freedom and the inner voice, about loss and memory, about social recognition and political struggle, about psychic energetics in language, about religion and reality and so much else... Students will be encouraged to chart their own course in this class. After wrestling with Plato's banishment of the poets from his Republic, for the midterm we'll each pick one poet and explicate their vision of poetry. For the final essay, we'll define the role of the poet in society for ourselves, whatever vision matters most to you. Along the way, we'll engage blogposts, interviews, and other texts from contemporary writers debating relevant topics. Students will also develop verbal reading skills through one oral performance of a poem and a final presentation sharing your research with the class. Don't worry if you don't know much about poetry yet a healthy curiosity is all that's asked. Lessons will develop the terms, tools, reading strategies and historical perspectives needed to engage these exciting and thought-provoking works. We'll trade quantity of reading for attention to the readings. Skills worksheets accompanying the readings will focus on issues like metaphor, paraphrase, rhetorical appeal, tone and flow, then later on researching, drafting, and finalizing our own written work. As a poet myself who has thought about these topics for years, I look forward to helping you produce your best work, writing a lot and thinking great thoughts. Books: Rainer Maria Rilke, Letters to a Young Poet (trans. Stephen Mitchell) Walt Whitman, The Portable Walt Whitman Emily Dickinson, Final Harvest We will only read excerpts from the Whitman and Dickinson collections, but it is still good to have them at hand for mind-wandering purposes. As the class aims to survey many poetic voices and theories, we'll also read individual poems from writers such as: Sylvia Plath, Robert Frost, T. S. Eliot, Adrienne Rich, Langston Hughes, Gwendolyn Brooks, Audre Lourde, W. B. Yeats, John Ashbery, W. H. Auden, E. E. Cummings, Wislawa Szymborska, Mahmoud Darwish, Paul Celan, Denise Levertov, Frank O'Hara, Hart Crane, Elizabeth Bishop, John Berryman, Jack Spicer, W. C. Williams, H.D., Kabir, Aurobindo, and closer contemporaries.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: "The Aesthetic, Vol. 1" Aesthetics, first used by Alexander Baumgarten as 'Ästhetik', and later as 'aesthetica', refers to the study of the nature of beauty and taste. With a more specific turn toward art today, the aesthetic allows us to ask an important question: what does it mean to judge an object and to call it beautiful? In "The Aesthetic, Vol. 1," we will trace the genealogy of aesthetics from its use as an appeal to life and perception in the history of philosophy, to popular culture, where to `like' someone's aesthetic, to `have' aura, and to `serve,' have become signature expressions of the contemporary use of aesthetic-related terminology. The course will begin with a general understanding of aesthetics specifically, aisthesis, beauty, and taste-- and will aim toward the presence of dreams and phantasy in the psychoanalysis of race, the nature and culture divide in sex/gender discourse, and the turn to the body in literary and art criticism. The texts of focus will be chosen from philosophers, such as, Georges Bataille, Immanuel Kant, Simon Gikandi, J. Gottfried Herder, David Marriott, Jean-Paul Sartre, and others. These philosophers will allow us to approach the field of aesthetics with some conceptual grasp and language to read objects in literature, film-cinema, contemporary and installation art, experimental media, music, and poetry. Thus, several of these objects will belong to writers, poets and artists, such as, Alexander Calder, Le Corbusier, Med Hondo, Eugene Hyde, Abdelkébir Khatibi, Thierry Kuntzel, Adolf Loos, Keith Piper, Donald Rodney, and others to be decided upon throughout the course. Required Assignments: Over the course of the semester, students will complete three one-page reading responses, one one-page piece of art criticism, upload collaborative annotations, and one final paper. Required Texts: All required and optional materials will be provided by the instructor. While we will not have the time to use some of the materials in their entirety, students are encouraged to utilize the online and physical copies of the following texts through Emory Libraries: George Bataille, Encyclopedædia Acephalica. David Marriott, On Black Men. Abdelkébir Khatibi, Love in Two Languages.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: "Let Black Kids Be Kids: Rethinking Black Childhood Through Literature and Media" Examining how narratives of Black youth shape and challenge cultural understandings of race, identity, and belonging, this course aims to explore the representation of Black childhood in literature, film, and other media (such as music and social media), in two different countries: Brazil and the U.S. Through an interdisciplinary approach, we will consider historical and contemporary portrayals of Black childhood, paying close attention to themes of joy, resistance, vulnerability, and how these factors challenge the very definition of childhood itself. Besides literature and media, students will also engage with critical theories on race, childhood studies, and media representation. We will explore key questions such as: (i) how do Black authors and creators redefine childhood? (ii) in what ways do systemic forces shape the experiences of Black youth in fiction and reality? (iii) how do storytelling and visual media contribute to broader discourses on race and justice? Readings may include works by Brazilian and American authors such as Toni Morrison, James Baldwin, Conceição Evaristo, and Eliana Alves Cruz, alongside films, television series, and social media content that center Black youth. Students will work on the topics of discussion through small writing assignments, reading responses, student-led discussion, a short research paper, and a creative project at the end of the semester.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course will focus on some of the most significant intellectual movements in literary theory and cultural criticism from the early twentieth century to the present: Formalism, the Bakhtin Circle, the Frankfurt School, Structuralism, Semiotics, Psychoanalysis, Poststructuralism, Feminism, Postcolonial Theory, Black Literary Theory, Queer Theory, Disability Studies, and Animal Studies. Although our class discussions and written assignments will be based on our assigned course readings, we may also draw from literature and other cultural forms beyond our readings in order to illustrate these different and sometimes conflicting theoretical approaches. In this course, not only will students learn about these different approaches to literature and culture and their relationship with one another, but they will also learn how to read theoretical texts and write scholarly papers. This course fulfills one of the five core course requirements for both the Major and Minor Degrees in Comparative Literature as well as the General Education Requirement (GER) in Continuing Writing (WRT) for Emory College. Texts: All assigned readings will be posted electronically on Course Reserves. Assessment: Four (4) response papers (2-3 pp. each, 40% total) Long essay (8-10 pp., 40%) Attendance and participation (20%)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ENG 345 1) (This course explores the literary transformation we typically call modernism which exploded in every region of the world under intensifying geopolitical conditions at the turn into the twentieth century. In this course, our aim however is not to delimit modernism aesthetically as a set of formal issues (like experimentation, subjectivity, or rejection of realism) or geographically (originating in European centers to be disseminated to the peripheries of the world). Instead, adopting a global perspective, we will discuss how "modernist" texts respond to and register shared foundational forces such as modernization as a historical phenomenon, global wars, nation-state makings, colonialism, and race, while tracing how such shared concerns and issues generate varying modernist projects and expressions. To deepen our understanding of how "modernist" authors engaged with global conditions, we will compare a set of novels from different parts of the world across temporal, political, and linguistic lines and establish connections between them in discussion and writing. Even as we study just a few texts, our aim is to gather a sense of these diverse yet interconnected literary movements around the globe and of the globalizing conditions that provoked them. In privileging a geopoetical perspective (which looks at geopolitical forces as well as formal variations), this course aims to provide a nuanced understanding of how modernity is experienced differently across the globe and to encourage students to analyze global modernisms in a comparative framework.) Readings include Virginia Woolf's Mrs. Dalloway, Ahmed Hamdi Tanpinar's The Time Regulation Institute, Alejo Carpentier's The Kingdom of This World, and Arundhati Roy's The God of Small Things.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as AMST 385 4, ENG 389 3, PHIL 385 2) In the wake of the "Great Resignation" and "lying flat" movements or the calls to "rage-" and "quiet-quitting" during pandemic times, and in response to recent writings in Marxist feminist and cultural studies circles on "postwork imaginaries," "breaking things at work," "doing nothing," or being "counterproductive," this seminar questions if there can ever really be an end to work. What does it take to effectuate such a radical promise or hope? Or is existence hopelessly shackled to work until retirement, if one can ever be free from such an ineluctability even then? This seminar will examine such questions through the lens of contemporary literary texts (Moshfegh's My Year of Rest and Relaxation, Raven Leilani's Luster, Ling Ma's Severance, Hilary Leichter's The Temporary, etc.) alongside critical theories of work (Marx, Lafargue, Barthes, Weeks, Han, Gregg, Sharma, etc.). Literary Texts: Ottessa Moshfegh, My Year of Rest and Relaxation Raven Leilani, Luster Ling Ma, Severance Hilary Leichter, The Temporary Adelle Waldman, Help Wanted The Zhuangzi Herman Melville, Bartleby, the Scrivener Franz Kafka, Metamorphosis Weike Wang, Notes on Work Theories: Karl Marx, on labor Paul Lafargue, The Right to Laziness Giorgio Agamben, The Use of Bodies Kathi Weeks, The Problem with Work Roland Barthes, The Neutral; "Doing Nothing"Byung-Chul Han, Burnout Society; Vita Contemplativa Sarah Sharma, In the Meantime Melissa Gregg, Counterproductive Gavin Mueller, Breaking Things at Work Guy Standing, The Precariat

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as PHIL 404W 1) German Romanticism This course provides an overview of some of the key figures and core concerns of the movement known as German Romanticism. Part of what makes German Romanticism unique is its blending of the philosophical and the poetic/literary in its quest for a language and form adequate to, or at least resonant with, what it seeks to present: the "Absolute." In this course, we will focus on the themes of system & fragment, romantic irony, the native/foreign opposition, conceptions of the feminine, and the problem of evil, reading Schlegel, Tieck, Hölderlin, Günderrode, Novalis, and Schelling, on the one hand, each supplemented by a reading from Blanchot, De Man, Heidegger, Wolf, Lacoue-Labarthe and Nancy, and Zizek, respectively, on the other. As such, this course hopes to show the ongoing relevance of German Romanticism for contemporary thought. Assignments Participation and Attendance Online Discussion Mid-term paper Final Paper Required Texts Schlegel, Friedrich. Philosophical Fragments. Ed. and trans. Peter Firchow. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 1991. Hölderlin, Friedrich. Selected Poetry. Ed. and trans. David Constantine. England: Bloodaxe Books, 1994. Günderrode, Karoline von. Poetic Fragments. Ed. and trans. Anna C. Ezekiel. Albany, NY: State University of New York Press, 2016. Novalis. Philosophical Writings. Ed. and trans. Stoljahr. Albany, NY: State University of New York Press, 1995. Schelling, Friedrich. Philosophical Investigations into the Nature of Human Freedom. Ed. and trans. Jeff Love and Johannes Schmidt. Albany, NY: State University of New York Press, 2005. Note: additional texts provided electronically on course reserves.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same ENG 483RW 1) "How we Read, or the Scales of World Literature" This course is interested in reading practices and paradigms (such as close, distant, thematic, comparative, relational, contrapuntal, connective, transnational) that underpin world literature. And it addresses various conceptualizations of scale and scaling as a way of exploring the myriad relations and connections established between texts and communities in world literature. Scales that run from granular, local, minor, or regional frameworks to macro analyses like world-systems, connected histories, deep time, planetarity, and/or the digital humanities. As we engage with the question of scale, we'll take up important discussions in the field, like how well literature travels and on what basis, the many modes of text and textuality, the ethical implications of close versus distant reading practices, the risks of comparison, the significance of interpretative communities, the dialectic between literature and history, the problem of linguistic difference, and what is lost or gained in translation. Some of our primary readings, subject to change, include J.M. Coetzee, Diary of A Bad Year, Sabahattin Ali's Madonna in a Fur Coat, Hamid Ismailov's Gaia, Queen of Ants, and Amitav Ghosh's In An Antique Land.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Prerequisite: CS 253 Department permission required, please email bnflood@emory.edu Spatial data is ubiquitous in many applications, e.g., map applications, agriculture, health, and transportation, and in different scientific disciplines, e.g., geographic information sciences, environmental sciences, and behavioral sciences. This course covers the main concepts behind the existing technologies in spatial computing and explores future directions where spatial data is driving innovations. The course starts by introducing spatial computing and geometric algorithms to handle spatial data including points, lines, and polygons. Then, the course further covers solutions for indexing, querying, and mining spatial data. Finally, spatial network algorithms and trends and innovations in spatial computing will also be covered.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course offers students a foundation for the study of East Asia [China, Japan, Korea] at the college level. Assigned texts include both primary and secondary works. We will encounter written documents, such as philosophical treatises, political writing and novels; material and visual objects, such as bronze vessels, paintings, and films; and scholarly writings on topics such as the history of East Asian languages, and the meaning of East Asia studies itself. All texts are in English or include subtitles. Textbooks: There are no textbooks to buy; some video materials may require access to subscription services like Amazon Prime Video but let the instructor know if you need an alternative. Works include archival materials preserved in Emory libraries, PDFs available for download through Emory Course Reserves, and images and videos available online. Grading: This course is based on student discussions, not faculty lectures. Assignments include 1) weekly comments using the Canvas discussion tool [grade: complete or incomplete], 2) team-based coordination of one class discussion per semester [individual grade according to rubric], 3) short writing assignments such film and journal article review [graded according to rubric], final exam. While this is a required course for majors in East Asian Studies, everyone is welcome. There are no prerequisites, and no prior knowledge of East Asia is necessary. The class is suitable for first year students. Required textbook: de Bary, et.al., Sources of East Asian Tradition, Volume 1, Columbia University Press, 2008.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as WGS 285W 1) Asian American Feminisms: This course will examine Asian Americanist approaches to studies of gender and sexuality. Key topics include negotiating familial gender roles and varieties of "coming out;" sexualization and desexualization in media; feminist disability politics (with starting points in Mimi Khúc's Dear Elia and Johanna Hedva's "Sick Woman Theory"); feminist, queer, and trans self-representations in popular and grassroots genres; and reimaginings of kinship beyond normative family structures. In addition to academic texts, our sources will include memoir, performance (comedy, drag, spoken word, TV), and fiction. Our analysis will emphasize feminist approaches to historical and contemporary modes of imperialism, exclusion, and exotification that mobilize skin color, citizenship, geopolitics, religion, and class in order to understand uneven conditions across Asian diasporas. We will also engage with Pacific Islander scholars and cultural workers to question what effects groupings like "AAPI," "APA," and "APIDA" have on attempts at queer and feminist solidarity.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: FREN 190 Freshman Seminar: Health and Illness / Prof. Bulakites TTh 11:30am-12:45pm (Limited to First Year Students Only) Content: This course will explore a seemingly paradoxical situation whereby France is consistently rated highly in terms of public health, yet its public healthcare system faces growing challenges and does not provide equally adequate care to all. Students will learn about the structure and functioning of the system as well as its foundational values and principles. They will also be introduced to public health systems in Canada, Haiti, Senegal, and other French-speaking countries for a comparative perspective. The specificities of public health for women, the LGBTQ community, and racial and ethnic minorities will also be addressed. Students will be encouraged to ask whose health is taken the most seriously and which illnesses are given the most attention and why. Texts studied include academic studies, novels, films, and articles and videos from the popular press.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: FREN 310 or FREN_OX 310 and FREN 314 or FREN_OX 314 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. FREN 351 (E. Darzi / MW 2:30-3:45pm) There is No Place Like Home Content: Amid a global migration crisis, hundreds of thousands seek refuge, either fleeing war or violence, escaping political oppression, persecution, or discrimination due to race, gender, ethnicity, religion, or a membership in a social group, or looking for a better future because of humanitarian crises, environmental disasters caused by climate change or financial insecurity and economic hardship. At the same time, nationalism, populism, and racism are on the rise, defining and restricting, ever more firmly, the borders of countries and the laws of citizenship. But all seem to be saying, at once: "I want a home!"But what is a home? Where is a home? When are you home? Who is home? How can one speak of a home? In this course, we will explore the question of the home in major 19th and 20th century Francophone and French texts as well as films and contemporary works of art. Through multiple disciplines including literature, philosophy, psychoanalysis, sculpture, painting, photography, video art, architecture, and film, we will go in and out of (conceptions of) the home. Instead of looking to build a monumental and monolithic home, this course will seek to examine the multiple, and, perhaps, infinite meanings this word can bear through its close relations to concepts such as family, space, individuality, consciousness, immigration, refuge, asylum, comfort, language, and memory. Class assignments will emphasize this multidisciplinary approach: assignments will include creative writing, co-curating an online exhibition, a midterm essay devoted to a close reading of a text or artwork, a group presentation, and a comparative final paper.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 218 1, JS 218 1) This course addresses the history of Nazi Germany from 1933 to 1945, a dictatorship that persecuted its political and racial enemies, rewarded those who complied with its political and racial vision, brought war to Europe and the world, and committed the crimes collectively known as the Holocaust. It offers a comprehensive overview of the origins, development, and outcomes of National Socialism. Topically, it covers the rise of the Nazi party, the establishment of the dictatorship, the life of Jews and social outsiders in Nazi Germany, the road to war, resistance to the Nazis, daily life in Nazi Germany, gender roles and sexual identity, as well as the medical crimes of euthanasia, and the Holocaust. This introductory course is designed for students without any prior knowledge of the subject and will focus on the reading of primary sources (original documents from the time period), combined with lectures and discussion. Assessment is based on active participation and written assignments (primary source analysis, film paper, take-home final).

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ARTHIST 221 1) (For millennia, the art and architecture of ancient Greece have been conceived of as foundational to the development of Western Art. The Parthenon, the Venus de Milo, and other works and imitations define modern cityscapes and museums. This course aims to consider the visual culture and the architecture of the peoples we understand as the ancient Greeks on their own terms, through an in-depth survey of the arts, architecture, and archaeology of Greek communities from the end of the Bronze Age to the Roman conquests (1050-150 BCE). Rather than viewing Greek art in isolation, this course examines it as a trans-Mediterranean phenomenon, shaped by dialogue, mutual artistic influence, and economic exchange with the millenary cultures of the Near East. Students will not only learn about cultural centers like Athens and canonical works of art and architecture but also explore the artistic productions of the wider ancient Greek diaspora, attested from the Iberian Peninsula to modern-day Afghanistan.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ARTHIST 222 1) Roman civilization, from the Republican through the Imperial periods, transformed the art and architecture of the ancient Mediterranean. Innovations in engineering and technique, the introduction of new materials (like concrete), and the Roman genius for cultural assimilation all combined to create an art which was exciting as well as eclectic. Indeed, Roman art has often been characterized as the first truly modern art. The course will investigate the ways in which major achievements in sculpture, painting, numismatic and glyptic art, as well as architecture often reflected contemporary developments in Roman politics, society and religion. In addition the course will explore the relationship of works of art and architecture erected in the city of Rome to those in the provinces, the interaction of public and official art to domestic art, as well as the impact of art commissioned by imperial and elite patrons on that commissioned by non-elite patrons. Art History major/minor: Division I Architectural Studies minor: elective

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This class will study the rise and fall of the world's first democracy. We will begin in the late sixth century BCE with the overthrow of the tyrant Pisistratus and the origins of Athenian democracy. We will end at the beginning of the fourth century BCE with the trial and death of Socrates following Athens' humiliating defeat at the hands of her rival, Sparta. Topics to be covered include: the new democracy's triumphs over the invading Persians; the growth of the Athenian empire; the city's nurturing of art and culture, which led to the beautiful architecture that still adorns the modern city and to the development of major new genres of literature, including tragedy, comedy, history, and philosophy; the plague at Athens and its role in the history of medicine. We will also discuss the political figures who helped Athens become strong and those who contributed to its downfall. The class will be run as a mixture of lecture and discussion.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ARTHIST 329 1) (Complete Topic - America Capta: Greek Art and Architecture in the United States) (This course critically examines the reception of Greek art and architecture in the United States from the late eighteenth century to the present. Through a systematic analysis of sites, buildings, monuments, and various artistic media, it explores how Greek architectural and visual forms have been appropriated, adapted, and contested over time. Topics include the influence of Greek architecture on public and private buildings and memorials; its association with white supremacy, particularly in the case of Nashville's Parthenon; the intersection of race and Neoclassical sculpture; and the role of Greek sculpture in American visual culture, from queer countercultures to 20th-century advertising and contemporary art.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ITAL 375W 1, CPLT 389W 1, and WGS 385W 2) (Complete Topic - Tragic Heroines: Writing Women Across the Centuries) (This seminar will examine the role that women have played in the process of writing tragedy and how they have come to be viewed as the bearers of tragic pathos from classical antiquity to the Renaissance. The classical tragic figure could be either male or female, but the Renaissance ushers in new gender roles and modes of viewing that significantly alter this paradigm. In this class, we will explore the causes and effects of female subjectivity, agency, and sexuality beginning with Sophocles Antigone in 441 BCE and until the publication of Valeria Maini's lesbian-centered heroine, Celinda, published in 1611 CE. We will also focus on numerous theoretical texts that deal with the aesthetics of tragedy, all authored by men, to see how tragedy became a vehicle to challenge and question prevailing civic structures through the gendered lens of writing the tragic, female experience. Texts to be read may include a selection: Sophocles - Antigone Euripides - Alcestis Euripedes - Medea Seneca -Thyestes Gian Giorgio Trissino - Sofonisba Giambattista Giraldi Cinzio - Orbecche Sperone Speroni - Canace Torquato Tasso - Aminta and Re Torrismondo Aristotle - Poetics Horace - Ars Poetica Salvatore Di Maria - The Italian Tragedy in the Renaissance Freud - The Interpretation of Dreams and Beyond the Pleasure Principle Lacan - Seminar VII: The Ethics of Psychoanalysis)

requirement_sentence: For sophomores and freshmen only. Certain great books and their authors have been influential across the centuries and continue to affect the way we think, act, and understand ourselves today. This course gives you the opportunity to study some of the most important among them, including Machiavelli's "The Prince," Adam Smith's "Wealth of Nations," Thomas Malthus's "Essay on Population," Karl Marx's "Communist Manifesto," Charles Darwin's "On the Origin of Species," and Sigmund Freud's "Civilization and Its Discontents." Strong emphasis on discussion; two papers, a midterm, and a final exam. The course is part of Emory College's Voluntary Core Curriculum.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as LACS 226 1, AMST 226 1) This course offers a survey of Latinx US History between the mid nineteenth through early twenty-first centuries. Following a chronological timeline, the course introduces students to major themes in Latinx history including, but not limited to, colonialism, migration, gender & sexuality, labor, politics, culture, and social movements. Together we will consider the genealogy and construction of Latinx as an ethnic category, the role of everyday Latinx people in the history and making of the US, and questions about historical and contemporary Latinx communities and identities.

In this course, we will work to answer these questions for ourselves while exploring how historians have studied the American South. In the process, we'll learn about the history of slavery, capitalism, race, gender, Native Americans, the American Civil War, Reconstruction, and the production and significance of historical memory.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course will train students to be peer health partners for the Health 100 course (taught during fall semesters). Students will be provided with an opportunity to become involved in a personalized approach to health and well-being by offering the tools to discover their own health and to develop healthy lifestyle behaviors. During the course, we will cover problems and issues relevant to Emory students, evidence-based approaches to health and wellness, and information on the resources and tools available at Emory for all students. Though designed to prepare students to facilitate and present to freshmen in Health 100, not all students who successfully complete this course will go on to do so. This course will benefit any student with an interest in health who also has the aim of broader intellectual development. This is an online course. Emory College Online summer courses have required synchronous/live sessions every week. Students must be available to sign into and virtually attend the course online during those times (noted as the course meeting times- all times listed are local to Atlanta). Each course will also involve significant asynchronous material that you access on your own time in addition to standard amounts of readings and course assignments. Students should plan to spend 15-20 hours/week on this course. Please also be aware that faculty will begin corresponding with students during Week Zero of the course (one week before the official start date of the course), and that some interaction with the course may be required at that time. Students should begin checking the Canvas course site regularly one week prior to the official start of the term.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: HLTH 220 or HLTH 221 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. An individual's nutrient and energy requirements change over the life span. This course will explore the nutritional foundations of growth, development, and normal functioning in each stage of the life span, from pre-pregnancy to older age. We will examine the physiological and developmental basis for changing nutrient requirements over each stage and consider evidence-based age- and life stage-specific dietary recommendations to prevent nutrient deficiencies, promote health, and prevent disease. Sociological influences across the lifespan will also be considered.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: When we sit down at the table to eat, many different factors influence our food choices and its preparation. In this course, students will learn and use evidence-based nutrition knowledge to examine the potential benefits of a plant-based diet. In addition, students will consider the potential influence of science, culture, sociology, economics and sustainability on these choices. Topics of investigation will be presented through a transdisciplinary perspective utilizing lectures and group discussions, hands-on cooking experiences, group projects and community engagement.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: HLTH 250 or HLTH_OX 250 or ANT 205 or ANTH_OX 205 or SOC 250 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. This course is a seminar style course that focuses on the interplay of major global health actors/players, the politics of global health, and the power dynamics that infuse the interplay. The course will concentrate on key global health players over the last 25 years including public, multilateral, private and philanthropic players. The landscape of global health was framed by the post-World War 2 set of organizations and institutions. Over the last 25 years and particularly since the millennium the landscape has fundamentally changed. This course will explore the dynamics of this change, the influence of respective global health players in crafting the global health agenda and the relative power of each player over time. A key focus of this course will interrogate the question of whether and how the priorities and politics of the big global health players influence decisions taken at community, sub-national and national levels in low and middle income countries. The course will require a significant amount of reading, critique, discussion and analysis. (HLTH 250 is a Prerequisite for this course)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 489RW 2, PORT 485W 1, SPAN 485W 1) Complete topic: The Public's Health in Latin America. What can the past teach us about the relationship between health equity and health access in Latin America. How does "Public Health" , as a profession and as an academic topic, connect to the public's health. This seminar focuses on how residents of Latin America understand health in their everyday lives. We will examine continuities and changes in approaches to healing, health, and disease over time by asking a series of related questions: How have patients and health professionals discussed disease, care, and cure? How have gender, ethnicity, citizenship status, and race shaped public health policies? In what ways did popular health practices figure into everyday life and national programs? How have global organizations engaged with everyday health through eradication and education programs? Students will investigate diverse actors through written, visual, and oral sources and will use primary documents and secondary material to analyze and construct arguments for their final research paper. Although our focus is on Latin America, the processes we will study were and are global in scope.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only) (This class examines the relationship between religion, self-care, and consumerism. We start with a simple premise; the way we take care of ourselves is political. Whether we realize it or not, many of us engage with religion in our daily lives. If you have seen Star Wars, used a yoga mat or meditation app, or attended a Burning Man festival, you have encountered religion. What does it mean when aspects of a religious tradition are transformed into consumer products? What cultural, ethical, and personal dilemmas emerge when religious ideas and objects are used for self-care separate from their religious context? Who decides which religions to borrow from, and which parts of those religions are 'extractible'? How do we approach practices like mindfulness, which have been scientifically proven to have health benefits, but are also sometimes viewed as a forms of cultural appropriation? Who can afford to participate in a consumerist wellness culture? Are there anti-capitalist forms of self-care? Can we imagine what our lives would look like if our society prioritized rest? These are all questions we will consider in this class. Students will have the opportunity to critically examine and experientially engage with contemporary self-care and wellness practices. This is a LINC class. During three of our sessions, we have discussions and practice self-care activities with Dr. Elaine Johnson's PSYC 190 Psychology of Wellbeing class.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: IDS 200W examines the origins of distinct disciplines in contemporary universities through the lens of evidence in different fields of human knowledge. // Recommended for students at any level interested in health sciences, law, business, or future studies at the graduate level. IDS 200W introduces students to the Liberal Arts and supports student's studies in a wide range of majors. Systematic focus on writing essential in any career. // What counts as evidence in different fields of human knowledge? Do we have evidence of things unseen, e.g. gods, tradition, love, existence after death, meaning? In the ancient tragedy "Antigone," for example, a young woman defies the law for love of her brother. But could the young woman's love, her thinking, speech patterns, and motivations be due to genetic dispositions, neural mechanisms, religious extremism, or mental disorder? Such questions highlight the problematic nature of evidence and explanation that we will examine.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 265 1) Nearly two billion people, almost a quarter of the world's population, live in South Asia. Spanning from the end of the end of the Mughal period and the beginning of Company Rule to the very recent past, this course offers undergraduates an introduction to the lively debates in the field of South Asian history. Questions students will be asked to consider include, but are not limited to: when does modernity in South Asia begin? How do we narrate the violence of Partition? What are some of the ongoing legacies of British colonialism? And how have historians attempted to recover the voices of South Asia's most marginalized? Reading assignments will introduce students to the "classic" works of South Asian history but will also feature the work of younger historians whose recent scholarship has enlivened old debates. Students will also work with a variety of media as part of their introduction to South Asian history. Aside from secondary literature, students will engage with novels, autobiography, and Bollywood film. While this course will only scratch the surface of South Asia's modern history, it aims to offer students a sense of the multiple ways in which to narrate South Asia's past.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 271 2, HIST 296 5) Full Title: The British Mandate for Palestine, 1917-1948: Empire and the Middle East It is only in recent years that the period of the British Mandate has come under rigorous academic scrutiny, with scholars focusing more attention on the aftermath of the 1948 War and its impact on the history of the Arab-Israeli Conflict. Yet the first struggles of this century-long conflict took place in the period of British rule lasting from 1917-1948. This course examines the history of British rule in Palestine, looking at the rise of Zionism and early Jewish settlement in the land, the formation of a distinctly Palestinian national identity amidst the rise of Arab nationalist movements, and the impact colonial rule had on both peoples. In what ways did this colonial experience shape Arab and Jewish identity in the Holy Land? What did the British Empire hope to achieve in Palestine, both strategically and for their colonial subjects?

HIST 448W 1, and POLS 448W 1) (Ever since the emergence of the Zionist movement in the late nineteenth century, the political future of the land known as both Israel and Palestine has been the subject of fierce international debate. This seminar will examine how, exactly, this land has been discussed in international forums and in various countries, as well as how leaders of both Israelis and Palestinians have worked to chart a foreign policy for their respective peoples. Students will be given an overview of Israeli foreign policy and Palestinian attempts at global outreach since 1948 before the course moves on to explore the politics of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in various regions of the world. Course requirements include regular preparation and participation, facilitating/co-leading classroom discussions, ten brief response essays, and a final original research paper. Most research papers will focus on Palestinian or Israeli foreign relations with another country, or the role of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in another country or region's politics, either historically or today. While there is no fixed prerequisite for the course, students should either have some background in the politics and history of Israel or the Middle East or have previous studied another country or region that they plan to examine in their research) (This is not an introductory course on the conflict. Those interested in an introductory course should enroll in the larger "Israeli-Palestinian Conflict" course to be taught in Spring 2026)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Students will cultivate an intellectual community with peers by attending weekly events, including lectures, art events, gallery walks, and performances. Most will be on campus, but a few will be in the Atlanta community. Students will gather together to discuss the event when it is concluded. Sometimes the conversation will include the performers, speakers, or organizers, and sometimes it will involve just the students and facilitators. Course meeting times will be based on the set event schedule, so the start and end times will vary. Usually, the course will meet for up to three hours, one day per week. Students will be asked to avoid scheduling any evening courses, and we will aim to have most events on Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday evenings. Each week, students will contribute short reflections to a digital map, documenting their intellectual and community journey throughout the course.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This survey course attends to foundational contradictions of collective life in US literary and cultural history through a focus on distinct US regions. For example, some populations move to or within U.S. regions to pursue different lives while others experience those movements as an imposition. Some populations choose to migrate while many others have movement, upheaval, and Removal forced upon them. This semester, we explore how communal experiences of movement, solidarity, and change are represented in literary and cultural histories created by people in what is now called the United States. Course work includes: reading annotations, a "Living Syllabus" project, and sustained analysis of literary, visual, and mass media examples.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 261 1) What does it mean to create literature in society that doesn't view you as fully human? This course will answer this question by examining black literary and cultural history. Spanning the eighteenth to turn-of-the-century, we will read early fiction and nonfiction to illuminate how the black writing tradition shaped American culture.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: In the white imagination, Black desire is occupied by two opposing stereotypes: for white liberals, Blacks simply and only desire freedom from racist oppression; for white supremacists, Blacks do not think beyond their desire for simple physical pleasures. Quite obviously, the reality is considerably more complicated. This class will take you through a century of canonical African American writers exploring Black desire, from Race Men and Club Women extolling the virtues of racial uplift to satirists gleefully calling attention to our very human foibles, and all those in between, puzzling over the complexity of being both human and symbol, hero and villain in the world's imagination. Through mini-lectures, small group analysis and full class discussions, we will take on the provocative yet rewarding challenges these essays and novels bequeath to us. To what degree does our social identity as African American restrict, mediate or perhaps heighten our desires? When our safety, livelihoods, and dignity are always under assault, how do our desires protect us or expose us further? Course work will include 10 written reader reactions, one midterm paper of 1250 words and one final paper of 2500 words. Attendance and participation in discussion also required. (SAME AAS 262W-1)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This class will introduce students to the literature of the Tudor period in England, extending from Henry VII's accession to the throne in 1485 to the death of Elizabeth I in 1603. The course is genre-comprehensive, including major works of poetry, drama, and prose. We will adopt a broadly historicist approach, considering texts within the political, economic, and social contexts in which they were produced. This approach, however, will not exclude attention to the formal and thematic qualities of individual works or the relevance of Renaissance texts to the present day. Topics to be discussed include Renaissance humanism, the Protestant Reformation, the political power of women, travel and colonialism, love and sexuality, and Elizabethan theater.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as AFS 389W 1) Topic: Writing Independence in and beyond Africa In this course we will explore some of the most powerful literary works produced by African writers since the start of decolonization in the 1950s. How do African writers imagine cultural, political, and personal independence? How have experiences of migration and of dissident sexuality inspired new kinds of literature? What kinds of freedom are at stake in these texts? Focusing on English-language fiction, this course will introduce the work of novelists Chinua Achebe, Bessie Head, and Jennifer Nansubuga Makumbi. We will also encounter multilingual worlds through the poetry of Safia Elhillo and Romeo Oriogun, as well as at least one classic and one contemporary film. We will have a chance to engage with an exhibition of contemporary African art at the Carlos Museum and to meet Oriogun, winner of the Nigeria Prize for Literature, when he visits Emory in October. Assessments will include weekly reading responses, two individual conferences, a literary analysis, a scholarly annotation, and a creative project but no research paper. In other words, we will meet the Continuing Communication requirement through frequent shorter compositions rather than a long high-stakes essay. GER tags: ETHN and HAPW

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: From medieval times to the present, the romance narrative has survived as one of the most enduring myths of western culture, despite questions about how well its Happily-Ever-After plot accurately depicts today's relationships. This course will analyze how five contemporary women novelists have rewritten myth, history, fairy tales, and science fiction to interrogate the traditional romance plot, from Cinderella to robots, as they explore current patterns in love and friendship. TEXTS: Rooney, CONVERSATIONS WITH FRIENDS; Conde, I, TITUBA, BLACK WITCH OF SALEM; Newitz, AUTONOMOUS; Carter, THE BLOODY CHAMBER; Atwood, PENELOPAID

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only) (Same as AAS 190 4) TOPIC: House: A Fiction Writing Workshop Focused on Structure(s). No application required. This is a class in which structure is both the craft concept and the content material. We will read stories and novels about houses in order to think through what these structures mean in our lives. We will use this learning to consider what architecture can teach us about the creative act of building stories and novels. We will write fiction that is attuned to narrative structure and to the role of structures in stories.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, you must attend the first class session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. In this introductory course, students will read short stories and learn the fundamentals of the craft of fiction. Special attention will be paid to sensory detail, imagery, style, and form. Students will learn to write toward their interests and obsessions, generate new work, and gain confidence and skill as writers. Most importantly, students will learn to read fiction - both published work and the original work of their peers'charitably and carefully, a fundamental skill for any creative practice. By the end of the course, students should come away with a deeper appreciation not just for craft, but for the diversity of artistic and intellectual enterprise that literature brings to bear on social life.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. Students must attend the first class to be enrolled in this workshop. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. This workshop will explore the art and craft of fiction writing. We will explore the essential elements of storytelling - character, plot, setting, structure, dialogue, scene construction - and how each is used in short fiction. Editing skills will be sharpened in discussion and evaluation of each other's work-in-progress. The course will concentrate on the creation of three short stories as well as technical consideration of technique, character development, and narrative structure, along with two revisions. Classes will be conducted as synchronous workshops/roundtable discussion in which the main emphasis is on the students' own work.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, you must attend the first class session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. This intermediate course is a space for experienced poets to further sharpen and expand their poetry practices in an intensive workshop environment. Over the course of the semester, we will explore the poem as a kind of hybrid research endeavor'an investigation driven by language and syntax. How do poets draw subjects, language, and even formal considerations for their poems from external sources such as historical records, interview transcripts, and art objects? In each class session, we will work towards a shared set of terms and ideas with which we might complicate our understanding of poetry's possibilities. We will read five poetry collections and a number of other poems, craft essays, and hybrid works across a range of English-language literary styles and traditions.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as THEA 372RW 1) (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, you must attend the first class session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. The instructor will be incoming Playwriting Fellow, PHANESIA PHAREL: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/people/bios/pharel-phan%C3%A9sia.html Application required. If accepted, you must attend the first class session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Plays are a human truth told in time. That truth is then brought to an audience to react, decide, reflect, and revolt. Plays are a singular democratic practice and gift in the human experience. Every single one of us has brilliant plays inside us, stories that connect others and help people feel alive, but how do we tell them? How do you figure out and access your truth - but more importantly, how can you make your truth legible to the outside world? In Intermediate Playwriting, we will be learning various elements of the craft, voyaging over a century worth of American playwrights to learn different tools and techniques, but more importantly for you to access what excites you and what themes you'd like your work to be in conversation with. In breaking down literary texts and exploring theatrical history, I often pose the central questions: What makes a play a play? What is theatricality? By investigating the foundations of story and identifying the elements that make a text theatrical, students develop a deeper understanding of both the craft and the medium. We will do this over a series of multiple exercises, and you will write a one-act play.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as THEA 375R 2) (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) In a round-table setting, students will workshop their own work, critique their fellows' work, and delve into the art of playwriting and dramatic narrative, while reading and acting in each other's scenes, and reading published work. Writing and reading intensive. Application required. If accepted, you must attend the first class session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. Both accepted and waitlisted students are required to attend the first class to be enrolled in this workshop. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. This workshop will introduce the fundamentals of writing personal nonfiction narratives. We will explore the basic elements of storytelling -- character, plot, setting, structure, dialogue, etc. -- and how each is used in creating a story out of the events of one's own life. Students will learn how to turn a true story into a written narrative. Editing skills will be sharpened in discussion and evaluation of one another's works-in-progress. The course will concentrate on the creation of three short nonfiction pieces as well as considerations of technique, creation of real characters, and dramatic structure. Classes will be conducted as workshops in which the main emphasis is on the students' own work, and short lectures, with some in-class writing and improvisation.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, you must attend the first class session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. "Too often in workshops and classrooms there is a concentration on the poem's garments instead of its life's blood," writes poet Linda Gregg in her essay "The Art of Finding." In this introductory course, we will, of course, address the fundamental "garments" of writing poetry, those essential poetic tools of craft. But, more than that, we will strive to tap into the experiences that compose our "life's blood" - those things that have shaped who we are, what we think, what we feel, and how we see the world. Each student should feel affirmed that the singularity of their lived experience lends them the power to write poems that no one else can write. Through considered attention to our work and that of our peers, and the close reading of work by other poets, we will find ways to make that "life's blood" sing.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: The most important conversations about science don't always happen in the lab. Many of us communicate about science when we do things like advocate for our health, speculate on our changing environment, and share our awe over the weird beauty of the natural and physical world. To meet this wide range of situations, effective scientist communicators face challenging questions: Are we saying this clearly? Is anyone listening? And are we sure we're right? In this course, students will produce written, visual, oral, and interactive media on topics including (but not limited to) COVID-19 and environmental justice. While this course may be of particular interest to students in science majors, it is intended for students in any major who are passionate about integrating scientific evidence and ideas into their work.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as QTM 302W 1) (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) (Go here to request a permission code: https://forms.office.com/r/2uiiNAgySW. Questions? Contact Sadie Hannans at shanna9@emory.edu.) (Technical Writing for Data Science - In this writing-intensive course, we will practice the effective and ethical communication of specialized technical knowledge and quantitative data. Because data are information given order, we will consider their arrangement and re-arrangement as rhetoric. We will introduce rhetorical analysis as a model for understanding how quantitative data can be interpreted and conveyed for multiple audiences that range from professional researchers to the lay public. Guided by this knowledge, you will exercise strategies for communicating via the text, speech, and visual conventions that are integral to preparing "technical" genres such as research reports, research translations, informative and persuasive infographics, instructions, and data repositories. We will adapt these genres and their conventions for our course goals that center collaboration, transparency, and reproducibility, while emphasizing the methodological questions to ask when bringing new purposes to data prepared by others, as well as whom to ask, and how. As you gain comfort with thinking of writing and analysis as intertwined practices of exploratory inquiry, we will focus especially on how these practices shape the social impacts of our data-driven narratives.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Cultural Rhetorics is a growing subfield of Rhetoric, Writing, and Literacy studies that poses a critical challenge to the discipline's foundations in Greek and Roman oratorical traditions. In this course, we will engage with a range of scholarly and creative work in Black, Asian, Indigenous, Latinx/Latine, Queer, and Disability studies, and engage with "rhetoric" as a set of practices tied to multiple understandings of "culture" and "community." This is a LINC course that will be co-taught with a Georgia State University class focused on Africana Methods, and students will meet for concurrent Zoom and in-person sessions over the course of the semester.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Course Topic: The American Civil Rights Movement: Local Links and Global Context This course is designed specifically for English-language learners. Its aim is to develop students: writing skills. As a thematic framework, we will consider Atlanta's role as the 'cradle' American civil rights movement. For our research projects, we'll make remote use of civil rights' era materials in Emory's Rose Library, including photographs, pamphlets, and recordings of speeches. To supplement our reading, we will also watch documentary films about this crucial time in U.S. history. This is an online course. Emory College Online summer courses have required synchronous/live sessions every week. Students must be available to sign into and virtually attend the course online during those times (noted as the course meeting times- all times listed are local to Atlanta). Each course will also involve significant asynchronous material that you access on your own time in addition to standard amounts of readings and course assignments. Students should plan to spend 15-20 hours/week on this course. Please also be aware that faculty will begin corresponding with students during Week Zero of the course (one week before the official start date of the course), and that some interaction with the course may be required at that time. Students should begin checking the Canvas course site regularly one week prior to the official start of the term.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: In the white imagination, Black desire is occupied by two opposing stereotypes: for white liberals, Blacks simply and only desire freedom from racist oppression; for white supremacists, Blacks do not think beyond their desire for simple physical pleasures. Quite obviously, the reality is considerably more complicated. This class will take you through a century of canonical African American writers exploring Black desire, from Race Men and Club Women extolling the virtues of racial uplift to satirists gleefully calling attention to our very human foibles, and all those in between, puzzling over the complexity of being both human and symbol, hero and villain in the world's imagination. Through mini-lectures, small group analysis and full class discussions, we will take on the provocative yet rewarding challenges these essays and novels bequeath to us. To what degree does our social identity as African American restrict, mediate or perhaps heighten our desires? When our safety, livelihoods, and dignity are always under assault, how do our desires protect us or expose us further? Course work will include 10 written reader reactions, one midterm paper of 1250 words and one final paper of 2500 words. Attendance and participation in discussion also required. (SAME AAS 262W-1)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course will provide a comprehensive overview of the writings of the seventeenth-century English poet John Milton, including his early lyric poetry, prose writings, and late major works. Much of the course will be devoted to a complete reading of Milton's masterpiece, the Biblical epic Paradise Lost. We will address his writing within its historical context, paying special attention to Milton's role in the English Civil War "during which he served as Latin secretary for the revolutionary Commonwealth government and was among the chief advocates of Puritan and republican values" and his relation to the changing gender roles of his time. We will also consider the major philosophical and religious themes of his writing, such as free will and the nature of divine providence.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Reading a wide array of texts drawing on lyric poetry, literary manifestos, slave narratives, plays, and personal letters, this course addresses romantic era writing with attention to themes of freedom, imagination, and autobiography. The romantic era roughly from the 1780's through the 1830's--was a time of highly charged debates about the role of literature in an increasingly modern society; the texts we will read explore different ways in which key writers of the time addressed the role of literature amidst the pressures of both economic and political upheaval. We will consider how these debates transformed the very language of literature and who and what counted as literary subjects. Figures an earlier literature might not have recognized as having a place in a supposedly elevated literary discourse enter romantic literature both as objects of representation and as the subjects of their own self-representation. And literature "itself" makes a radical claim for its own creative and sustaining powers.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as AFS 389W 1) Topic: Writing Independence in and beyond Africa In this course we will explore some of the most powerful literary works produced by African writers since the start of decolonization in the 1950s. How do African writers imagine cultural, political, and personal independence? How have experiences of migration and of dissident sexuality inspired new kinds of literature? What kinds of freedom are at stake in these texts? Focusing on English-language fiction, this course will introduce the work of novelists Chinua Achebe, Bessie Head, and Jennifer Nansubuga Makumbi. We will also encounter multilingual worlds through the poetry of Safia Elhillo and Romeo Oriogun, as well as at least one classic and one contemporary film. We will have a chance to engage with an exhibition of contemporary African art at the Carlos Museum and to meet Oriogun, winner of the Nigeria Prize for Literature, when he visits Emory in October. Assessments will include weekly reading responses, two individual conferences, a literary analysis, a scholarly annotation, and a creative project but no research paper. In other words, we will meet the Continuing Communication requirement through frequent shorter compositions rather than a long high-stakes essay. GER tags: ETHN and HAPW

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 385W 1) Topic: Black Archives An archive is meant to preserve records of enduring value for future generations. In our society, however, what is recorded is determined by the values of the person doing the recording, resulting in the absence of anyone who is not a white man from many written historical records. In the case of enslaved people, for example, we seldom have a written record of what they called themselves, who they loved, and what they believed. Searching through the records of plantations and slave ships, scholar Saidiya Hartman devised a method called critical fabulation to write about the personhood of enslaved people by "straining against the limits of the archive to write a cultural history of the captive." This class will use archives at the Rose Library and other locations to teach students to practice different types of archival methodologies. We will begin by practicing critical fabulation to explore the gaps in written records about enslaved people. We will move on to practices of remembrance within our own families, conducting genealogical research and oral history. We will then explore the Rose Library's abundant collections of archives donated by Black writers, artists, and activists, detailing some of the most intimate details of their lives through diaries, drafts, and correspondence. The final project will ask students to archive documents related to a social, political, or cultural group that they belong to.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Preferred per-requisite: ENVS 120, 130 or 140 The goal of this course is to provide an overview of the central debates in Environment and Society by exploring current environmental topics from an environmental science and geographic perspective. The course examines how humans impact the environment and how the environment, in turn, shapes human societies. We will examine these struggles in a North-South context using the concept of sustainability to understand the contested implications of several issues, including population growth, resource scarcity, food and agriculture, climate change, economic growth, biodiversity, water, technology, hazards, French fries, and environmental justice. Critical attention will be paid to ethics and inequalities in power, lifestyles, consumption patterns, and resource access. The importance of scale and global interconnectedness, particularly when assessing the costs and benefits of sustainability, will be discussed. This course offers students a unique opportunity to reflect on "their place" in the world to local and global sustainability. There are no prerequisites for this course.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as POLS 370A 1, SOC 370A 1, CBSC 370A 1) This course examines how communities of all sizes and types (e.g., neighborhoods, cities, metropolitan regions) solve important public problems. Our focus will be on understanding how, why, and to what effects, collaborative, community-based, cross-sector (public-private-nonprofit) initiatives are crafted. The course addresses several tensions and issues that affect the practice of community building, and the processes through which community builders attempt to overcome these obstacles to foster social change comprehensively (e.g., reduce poverty and promote economic mobility) as well as within specific policy domains such as education, economic development, workforce development, health, and the environment, among others. We will explore the course material through lectures, individual and group exercises, and the examination of a variety of case studies of comprehensive community initiatives launched over the past 30 years. This course is a requirement for participation in Emory's Community Building and Social Change Fellows Program, though students do not need to commit to participating in the CBSC program to enroll. For more information on the CBSC program see https://www.emorycbsc.com/ or contact the CBSC program director, Kate Grace, at kdgrace@emory.edu.

requirement_sentence: ENVS 120 or ENVS 130 or ENVS 131 or ENVS_OX 131 or ENVS 140 or (BIOL 142 and BIOL 142L) or BIOL_OX 142 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. (Same as BIOL 371 1) This 2-credit hour lecture course will explore the diverse biomes of the tropics. The focus will be on tropical forests and grasslands, with an emphasis on ecological processes, biodiversity, human impact on the tropics, indigenous peoples, and ethnobotany. Prerequisites: Biology 142 and Biology 142L (for Biology 371). This course is taught by Dr. Larry Wilson (adjunct faculty), is SHARED by the Biology and Environmental Science Departments, and may be taken as elective credit for the biology major. There is also an optional field course/lab associated with this course that travels to Peru during Spring Break (see BIOL 372/ENVS 372).]

title: COURSE ATLAS

(Same as BIOL 372 1) This 2-credit hour field course is part of the Office of International and Summer Programs (OISP) and will be taught during Spring Break week (March _____, 2025) in the Amazon River lowland rainforests of southern Peru (Tambopata Research Station), famous for its huge flocks of colorful Macaws. This field course will give the student a real hands-on rainforest experience complete with bromeliads, toucans, sloths, and the sounds of the night. Graduating Seniors and students who have previously completed BIOL 371/ENVS 371 have priority for this course. Cost for the trip is approximately $3200 (depending on airfare prices). Permission of instructor is required. This course is taught by Dr. Lawrence Wilson (lwilso3@emory.edu; adjunct faculty), is SHARED by the Biology and Environmental Science Departments, and may be taken as elective and upper-level laboratory credit for the biology major. Biology majors may submit an application to Barbara Shannon at barbara.shannon@emory.edu. Selected students will be notified and will have additional requirements by OISP. See the OISP website for additional information. Financial Aid scholarships from the Biology Department are available to eligible students who submit an application for the aid.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as PHYS 380 3) Prerequisite MATH 111 or permission of instructor This in an introductory class into a broad range of physical processes taking place in the Earth's atmosphere. The class is targeted at advanced undergraduate or early graduate students with diverse backgrounds in environmental sciences, physics or math. The material taught in this class emphasizes physical concepts, which are derived from the first principles. While formal training in thermodynamics, radiative transfer, or fluid mechanics is not required, this course is recommended for students with analytical skills and basic undergraduate physics and calculus background. Together with ENVS385 Introduction to Atmospheric Physics, this course lays out the foundation for understanding current and future climate.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course will teach the fundamental principles of remote sensing and provide hands-on training using case studies focused on applications of remote sensing in environmental science. Students will learn the basic principles of satellite remote sensing through computer labs and case-studies based on real environmental problems where they will receive training in how to collect, process and analyze environmental information derived from earth-orbiting satellites.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course aims to understand and explore forests as landscapes of Indigenous presence in Atlanta and the broader southeast region through systems of Indigenous foods and forest stewardship. We will explore and ponder two objectives through the course: 1) relational accountability through forests and 2) how the past structures the present of forests in the southeast and how the past can guide present forest stewardship and relationships. We will cover topics related to ethnobotany and forest foods, wild concepts and myths, food sovereignty, colonization and forests, Indigenous forest stewardship, environmental change, co-management, and more. This class is a land-based course, meaning a portion of our learning will be done in forests and with people in and around Atlanta and the broader region. We will substitute one or two weeks with weekend field trips- one overnight and one day trip. We will engage in reciprocity with forests and the people we engage with in this course and consider what that means to us as a classroom community. This is a project-based course with students focused on the development of a larger body of work throughout the semester related to course objectives. This course is linked with Dr. Malinda Lowery's course on Indigenous Sovereignties in the Department of History. Students will have the opportunity throughout the semester to co-engage with her course and some topics will overlap between the two courses. There are no pre-requisites, but students are best prepared by taking courses in Indigenous studies, ENV285 Biocultural Environments, botany, or ecology. Students are encouraged to also prepare by reading up on foundational concepts in Indigenous Environmental Sciences. Dr. Mucioki is happy to suggest readings.
