title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Tradition-Hinduism. An introduction to the Bhagavad-Gita, a Sanskrit philosophical poem and one of the most famous Hindu scriptures. When the warrior Arjuna surveys the field just moments before battle, he begins to second-guess his decision to fight. Is victory worth all the lives about to be lost? Is he prepared to kill his own family and friends fighting on the other side? Won't civil war destroy the norms and bonds of the political community? The Bhagavad-Gita contains the god Krishna's answers to such questions. While Krishna's teaching starts out as a "tough love" pep talk, it soon turns into a stunning lecture touching a wide range of philosophical themes, including selfhood, free will, the structure of action, the ground of being, and love. Our primary goal will be to read the Bhagavad-Gita in English translation, closely and in its entirety. Many of the course readings will help us situate the Gita in its various contexts' historical, religio-philosophical (e.g., Vedic ritualism, Vedanta, Sankhya, Yoga), and narrative (the Gita forming one section of a much larger epic). As we work to understand Krishna's complex teaching, we will also make use of the Gita's vast commentarial tradition, consulting traditional commentators such as Shankara, Yamuna, and Ramanuja, as well as modern authors such as M.K. Gandhi, Sri Aurobindo, and B.R. Ambedkar.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 341 1, PHIL 385 3) This course explores the moral and political thought of one of the great thinkers of the Middle Ages and arguably the most important Jewish philosopher of any age, Moses Maimonides (sometimes known in Hebrew as Rambam). Maimonides (1135-1204) was a jurist, philosopher, communal leader and physician. He was deeply steeped both in the Greco-Islamic philosophical tradition (i.e., Plato and Aristotle via writers like Alfarabi, Avicenna and Al-Ghazali) and was also an unparalleled master of the entire rabbinic and biblical corpus. This makes him of special interest to students across a wide variety of areas, including religion, philosophy, politics, Jewish Studies and Middle Eastern Studies among others. No single student is likely to have a background in all these areas, so I want to emphasize that there are no prerequisites for the course. It would be silly to think that knowing Hebrew or Arabic are not helpful, but all of our readings will be in English translation; knowing something about philosophy or Judaism is of course helpful but is not required.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as WGS 385W 1) Queerness is often positioned in intuitive opposition to "religion." Without assuming necessary antagonism, we will consider how queer religious subjects navigate identity, embodiment, and gender and sexuality's relationships to other forms of social difference. This course will situate queer religious subjectivities in wider fields of debate about the power relations that shape normative understandings of religion, gender, and sexuality, including contestations over whose voices are trustworthy and authoritative. We will consider collective and ecstatic experiences in ritual, mysticism, community formation, and spirit possession and ask what kinds of queer knowledge these contexts might reflect and generate. Course readings will take theoretical, theological, anthropological, and creative approaches to questions like: How do religious commitments shape queer relational and sexual ethics? How does devotion to divinities and spirits relate to love between humans? Are queer ways of being somehow religious or spiritual even when they do not identify with a particular tradition? Is "queerness" in religion primarily a mode of interpreting sacred texts, a matter of practitioners' sexual orientations, an approach to collectivity, or something else entirely?

title: COURSE ATLAS

Thematic emphasis may include relationships of text and context, pilgrimage, gender, epic performance, religious institutions, visual arts, or colonial and post-colonial identities.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (HLTH 250 1, ANT 205 1) This interdisciplinary course explores the complex causes of serious health problems in both low-income and rich countries throughout the world, as well as strategies of health programs aimed at their solution. Global Health refers not only to the health problems of "others" living in far corners of the world but also to our own health problems as citizens of a very rich nation; most importantly it is about how those health problems are the result of global, social, economic and political interactions.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Course description: In this course we will examine how the social organization of American society, its culture, and institutions influence mental health and illness. We will explore three broad areas of the sociological study of mental illness which include definitions and measurement of mental illness; its social origins; and societal processes through Western and decolonial perspectives. By scrutinizing Western (American) ideologies we will be better able to articulate how mental health and illness is a product of social circumstances like interpersonal, institutional, and cultural factors, rather than just the result of biological (or genetic) and individual-level factors. Through a decolonial lens, we will decenter white supremacy and propose solutions to improve mental health by reducing inequality and the impact of colonialism while incorporating culturally-affirming practices from Black and First Nations people. Learning objectives: 1. Explain the social construction of mental illness. 2. Describe the social distribution of mental health and illness. 3. Compare and contrast theoretical approaches to the study of mental health and illness. 4.Critically assess social antecedents and consequences of mental health and illness.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as LING 446W 1 & QTM 446W 1) The course deals with new tools of analysis and visualization of text data. It is a 4-credits course, fulfilling the writing requirement with extensive weekly writing. The course does NOT require any prerequisites or prior knowledge of computational tools. Freshmen are not allowed to register. Text corpora will be assigned for analysis but students are welcome to use their own texts (e,g., newspaper articles, books, blogs). The course is based on a set of specialized Natural Language Processing tools (NLP), written in Python, designed for the analysis of small/large corpora of text. The tools come with an easy-to-use Graphical User Interface (GUI). From sentence splitter, to tokenizer, lemmatizer, parser with its Part-of-Speech tags (POSTAG), Dependency Relations (DEPREL), Named Entity Recognition (NER), semantic trees, sentence complexity and text readability, noun and verb analysis, n-grams viewer, sentiment analysis, topic modelling, extraction of SVOs (Subject-Verb-Object), and shape of stories, word embeddings (Word2Vec) you will learn the language of Natural Language Processing (NLP). The course also embeds tools of data visualization as word clouds, Excel-type charts, network graphs, and Geographic Information System (GIS) maps. The course uses freeware software exclusively. The course has no required books.

title: COURSE ATLAS

(This course examines the development of sociological theory and conveys its diverse insights by analyzing the ideas of major theorists, placing those ideas in context, testing them against recent evidence, and applying them to contemporary issues.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (SOC 101 is designed specifically for sophomores and first year students; enrollment does not open until those course registration times. Very occasionally a junior, but not a senior will find enrollment off the waitlist, which opens only after first year and soph enrollment. This course will provide students with an overview of the sociological approach. Major theoretical concepts and methodologies will be examined and illustrated with a wide variety of classic as well as recent empirical studies. Some of the topics we'll look at include: social structure and culture in everyday life; societal views of death; socialization to gender roles; causes and consequences of major systems of social inequality (gender; race and ethnicity; social class). Requirements: Weekly readings, two papers, and two exams.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: CONTENT: Spanish 101 is a beginning-level integrated skills language course for students with no background in Spanish or only one year of high-school Spanish. The goals of this course include learning to use Spanish to communicate, learning of and about the tools of communication and studying Hispanic cultures to begin to understand how culture affects language use. Students participate in paired, small-group and whole-class conversation/listening activities that focus on meaningful communication and are required to do short readings and complete writing assignments. REQUIRED COURSE MATERIAL: Contraseña: Your Passport to Foundational Spanish (LingroLearning) + LinguaMeeting. Contraseña is a completely mobile and digital immersive experience, so there is no required printed textbook. Access is available for purchase directly from LingroLearning at www.lingrolearning.com PARTICULARS: Classes are conducted in Spanish to maximize exposure to the language. Evaluation is based on daily and active participation, online homework assignments, and portfolio projects. Friday classes will meet via Zoom for 50 minutes when there are no LinguaMeetings scheduled. PREREQUISITE: None, but students must take the Spanish Placement Exam and receive an Official Placement for SPAN 101 from the Department of Spanish and Portuguese. Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Spanish 111 is an accelerated beginning-level language course designed to advance students towards a higher level of proficiency in both communication in the Spanish language and cultural knowledge of Hispanic communities. The course is intended for students with previous education in Spanish who need additional review and practice before advancing to the intermediate level. The goals of this course include the following: 1. Further improving communicative ability through speaking, listening, reading and writing skills; 2. Developing a more complex understanding of the tools of communication: basic linguistic units (words, idioms, verb forms, sounds) and grammar (rules which permit you to combine the units meaningfully); 3. Facilitating advancement from a primarily receptive to a productive use of the language; 4. Expanding cultural awareness, familiarity with and understanding of Hispanic cultures. and understanding of the relationship of culture to language. Prerequisite: Official Spanish Placement into Span 111 is required to remain in the course. (Take the Spanish placement exam online at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as PORT 185 1) (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) (Community engagement for residents of Casa Émory (Theme Housing). This course involves weekly meetings and discussion, planning of community events, and participation in other group activities. Fall Casa Émory residents are usually selected in February, but spaces sometimes become available at other times. Please contact the instructor for more information. This class meets in Casa Émory.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: CONTENT: This course, which is the first half of our intermediate sequence in Spanish and intended to be followed by Span 202, continues to develop students' communicative skills in Spanish and is designed for students who have fewer than four years formal experience studying Spanish and/ or who do not identify as heritage or native speakers of Spanish. While reviewing and acquiring new vocabulary, grammar, and pronunciation are central, learning about Hispanic/ Latino cultures is an integral part of the course as we will discuss our personal experiences and values, along with differences and changes among Spanish-speaking communities throughout the world. To this end, Span 201 aims to help students - continue to learn to use Spanish to communicate via active (speaking and writing) and passive modes (listening and reading); - further develop their knowledge of and about the tools of communication: basic linguistic units (words, idioms, conjugations, sounds) and grammar (rules which permit you to combine the units meaningfully); - explore, appreciate, and reflect upon a variety of Hispanic/ Latin/ Latinx cultures to critically discuss, compare, and analyze cultural productions. REQUIRED PROGRAM: Contraseña: Your Passport to Foundational Spanish (LingroLearning), a completely mobile and digital immersive experience. There is no required printed textbook. Purchase access to Contraseña directly from LingroLearning. PARTICULARS: Classes are conducted in Spanish, and daily attendance and active engagement are expected. EVALUATION is based on active participation and timely completion of homework, end-of-unit cumulative activities or quizzes, end-of-unit projects, and bi-weekly online meetings with coaches who are native speakers of Spanish. There is no final exam in SPAN 201. PREREQUISITES: SPAN 102, SPAN 111 or an Official Placement for SPAN 201 from the Department of Spanish and Portuguese. If you haven't done so already, be sure to take the required online Spanish Placement exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/exam.html well before fall semester starts.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: SPAN 201 or SPAN_OX 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. This is an online course. Emory College Online summer courses require weekly synchronous/live sessions. Students must be available to log in and attend these sessions virtually at the scheduled times (listed in Eastern Time, local to Atlanta). In addition to the live sessions, each course includes substantial asynchronous material, which students must engage with on their own time, along with regular readings and assignments. Students should expect to dedicate 15-20 hours per week to the course. Faculty will begin reaching out to students during Week Zero (one week before the official course start date), and some interaction with course content may be required at that time. Students should begin checking the Canvas course site regularly one week prior to the official start of the course. This course is a continuation of Spanish 201 and is designed to further develop students' Spanish skills. Students refine their grammar usage through continued review of basic structures and study of complex structures, and they expand their spoken Spanish skills through discussion and analysis of cultural topics, personal experiences, and literary and journalistic texts. Students are provided ample opportunity for focused listening through use of recorded texts (conversations, music, video) and for oral expression through general classroom and small-group discussions and oral reports. Readings in the course focus on both historical and current cultural and social issues in the Hispanic World. Writing is also developed as a communicative endeavor, with emphasis on the preparation of written compositions/reports based on the cultural components of the course. PREREQUISITE: SPAN 201 or SPAN_OX 201 ****For enrollment, contact Sharlene Arruda Mendes at sharlene.arruda.mendes@emory.edu****

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: CONTENT: This course focuses on developing both cultural understanding and linguistic skills. It explores cultural issues in the Hispanic world, such as diversity, gender roles and power structures through writing about and discussion of written texts and films. These texts also serve as the basis for practicing Spanish vocabulary and grammar in context, as well as honing listening, speaking, and particularly, reading and writing skills. By the end of the course, students should be able to use critical thinking skills in Spanish to interpret and discuss literature and film in Spanish, gain advanced proficiency in reading and writing the language, and gain knowledge of significant historical events. REQUIRED TEXT: Coutard, James, Evelyn, Katryn, Gaspar, Martin. Intrigas, 3rd ed. VHL, 2021. PARTICULARS: Movie screenings will be required outside of class. EVALUATION: Class participation, chapter quizzes, weekly homework, presentations, unit lesson essays. PREREQUISITE: SPAN 202 or Official Spanish Placement for SPAN 212. Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at https://spanport.emory.edu/undergraduate/placement/index.html SPAN 212 may be combined with a Spanish Foundational Course (300-318) or PORT 110 to satisfy both the HAL or Intercultural Communication requirement and major/minor requirements or electives. See https://spanport.emory.edu for details.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Spanish for Business Communication In an age where Spanish is emerging as a dominant global business language, understanding the nuances of "doing business" is paramount. This course, tailored to intermediate to advanced Spanish learners, will immerse students in culturally-relevant, communication contexts connected with organizations within the Spanish-speaking world. By the end of the course, students will possess a robust foundation of the vocabulary and communication practices used for commerce, management, office practices, human resources, and marketing. Students will also develop their geographic literacy, critical thinking, and intercultural communication skills. PREREQUISITE: Spanish 212 or Official Spanish Placement for a Foundational Spanish Course. Take the Spanish Placement Exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: CONTENT: Discussion of current events in the Spanish-speaking world with emphasis on listening comprehension and oral expression. PARTICULARS: Oriented toward Spanish, SpanPort, and SpanLing majors and minors. Does not fill HAL/IC or other general education requirements. PREREQUISITE: SPAN 212 or placement.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as CPLT 201W 2) (Topic: Iberoamerican Literature in Secret) Alluding to the text "Literature in Secret" by Algerian and French literary theorist Jacques Derrida, this course considers how the experience of literature in the Iberian and Latin American traditions might both enable and resist the many histories such tradition engenders. Marked by the ravages of empire and coloniality, these geographical spaces have produced and continue to produce a political and social fabric structured around the oscillation between secrecy and revelation. Surveillance, control, and order are but some of the techniques that regulate who or what remains hidden or exposed. We will argue that and examine how these mechanisms might lose their power in literature, and how literature could open to other modalities of secrecy beyond inquisitorial and colonial world-making. This course understands literature as a site and mode of thinking and experiencing, rather than a category of classification. For this reason, we will read poetry, drama, and short stories, as well as historical, theoretical, and religious texts, where we will encounter secret properties of plants, the poetry of forbidden religions, undercover runaways, ghosts, talking dogs, and lost diaries, among other poetic scenes. Our work during the semester will examine topics such as the possibilities and difficulties of telling stories and writing history, the necessary conditions of meaning, the poetics of political legitimacy, and the fantasies of national belonging. Our work during the semester will examine topics such as the possibilities and difficulties of telling stories and writing history, the necessary conditions of meaning, the poetics of political legitimacy, and the fantasies of national belonging. Some of the authors we read might include Miguel de Cervantes, Maria de Zayas, Rosario Ferré, Jorge Chagas, and Roberto Bolaño.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course offers students an overview of early Spanish and Spanish American texts and cultures, ranging from the late middle ages (15th century) to the threshold of modernity (late 17th century). Students will develop their ability to interpret culture and history through engaging with a wide range of textual genres (novels, short stories, lyric and narrative poems, letters, histories) and paintings produced in Spain and Spanish America spanning three centuries. In addition to exposing students to various sources to help them develop their interpretive and linguistic skills, this course also invites them to think about the formation of the Spanish American world through three main conceptual notions: movement, dialogue, and identity. Each module in this course challenges students to think of how movement impacts a person's perspective, how authors and artists respond to one another in transoceanic dialogues that span decades, and how a person's identity is shaped by their lived experience, as well as their frames of reference to examine their own experience. Readings may include Fernando de Rojas, Lazarillo de Tormes, Jorge de Montemaior, Catalina de Erauso, Miguel de Cervantes, Luis de Góngora, Sor Juana, Motolinia, Bartolomé de Las Casas, Ana Caro, Clarinda, Inca Garcilaso, Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala, Fernando de Alva Ixtlilxochitl, Diego Muñoz Camargo, and others. Taught in Spanish, with readings in Spanish.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: CONTENT: Spanish 302W is one of the foundational courses for the major and minor in Spanish. This course has a transatlantic and interdisciplinary approach and introduces students to the analysis of cultural texts (novel, poetry, art) in Spain and Latin America from the eighteenth century to the present. PREREQUISITE: SPAN 212 or Official Placement for a Foundational Course (Span 300-318) from the Department of Spanish and Portuguese. Take the Spanish Placement Exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as LING 303 1) This course, taught in Spanish, focuses on the linguistic study of the diverse pronunciations of Spanish. It explores how sounds are produced (articulatory phonetics), how they are organized in Spanish (phonology), and how these compare and contrast with typical pronunciations of English. The course also considers how speakers use the sounds of Spanish to perform and interpret regional/social identities and roles in communitive interactions within Spanish-speaking communities of Latin America, the US, and Spain. TEXT:Tuten, D. N., Tejedo-Herrero, L. F., R. Rao, & H. R. Clarke. 2022. Pronunciaciones del español(Routledge).PARTICULARS: This course is designed for a wide variety of students, including those for whom Spanish is a primary or heritage language as well as for those who are learning Spanish as a second language. This is an introductory course in Hispanic Linguistics and therefore no background in Linguistics is required. Span/Ling 303 is a core course for the Spanish and Linguistics Joint Major and a Foundational Course for the Spanish Major and Minor. If SPAN 303 is at full capacity, please consider enrolling in LING 303, which will satisfy the same major requirements, as well as the IC requirement. EVALUATION is based on attendance/participation, homework assignments, exams, and dialect exploration projects. PREREQUISITE: SPAN 212 or an Official Spanish Placement into our Foundational Course level (Span 300-318). Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html. For more information on Foundational Courses, please go to www.spanport.emory.edu).

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as LING 304 1) CONTENT: In June 2020 the Supreme Court ruled that the section of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 that outlaws employment discrimination on the basis of sex must be interpreted to also protect gay and transgender people. The whole basis for this ruling was the analysis of the specific language used in the Civil Rights Act, however, how do words convey meaning? How are words' meaning established and by whom? How does language portray real world situations? This course, taught in Spanish, explores answers to these questions by presenting students with fundamental concepts in Linguistics through a comparison between Spanish and English at different levels: the sounds of languages (phonetics and phonology), the structure of words (morphology), the structure of sentence (syntax) and the study of meaning (semantics and pragmatics). The course also incorporates an introduction to linguistic variation in the Spanish-speaking world, including the Spanish spoken in the US, and how languages evolve and change with time (historical linguistics). EVALUATION is based on active class participation, exams (two midterms) and homework assignments. Spanish/Linguistics 304 is a core course of the Spanish & Linguistics Joint Major and a foundational course for the Spanish Major and Minor. If SPAN 304 is at full capacity, please consider enrolling in LING 304, which will satisfy the same major requirements, as well as the IC requirement. PREREQUISITE: SPAN 212 or an Official Spanish Placement into our Foundational Course level (Span 300-318). Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: DESCRIPTION: This course is designed specifically for heritage speakers: students who already speak Spanish and come from a Spanish-speaking family (typically their parents or grandparents speak this language); they have however never been schooled in Spanish or have received limited education in Spanish. The course introduces students to the study of the Spanish language and cultures in an academic context, and it is divided in three parts: 1) a sociohistorical background on the presence of the Spanish language in the United States, 2) a study on language variation and language ideologies, with a specific focus on the dialectal characteristics of US Spanish and how they differ and connect to other Spanish dialects, 3) a methodology for the critical analysis of cultural production in Spanish, such as films, literary works, music, etc. EVALUATION: Evaluation will be based on class participation, daily assignments, one exam, one oral presentation and three essays. PRE-REQUISITES: Heritage speakers of Spanish who have an official placement for foundational courses, or have completed Span 212, or with permission from instructor.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: CONTENT: Storytelling is universal; narratives are often thought of strictly as literature or art, but narrative is in fact something we engage in on a regular basis in all spheres of daily life. At the same time, narratives are situated in specific cultural contexts. This course will highlight Spanish-language literature and other forms of storytelling (film, visual and digital texts, journalism) from Spain, Latin America, and the U.S. that are expressions of citizen protest, analyzing how narrative genres and strategies are used to communicate these texts' messages to their audiences. Course texts are drawn from protests associated with environmental activism, indigenous movements, student movements, feminism and gender protests, critiques of economic neoliberalism, pro-democracy movements and defense of human rights. SPAN 311 is one of the foundational courses for the Spanish major and minor. PREREQUISITE: Spanish 212 or an official Spanish placement for a Foundational Course level (Span 300-318). Students wishing to enroll without this prerequisite should consult the instructor. Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This 300-level course is designed to equip advanced Spanish learners with the practical language skills and cultural understanding necessary to thrive in the global business environment and workplace. Moving beyond traditional textbook exercises, this course centers on experiential and project-based and practicum-based learning. Students will participate in mock simulations, conduct in-depth research on the economies and business practices of Spanish-speaking countries, and also develop their own professional portfolios relevant to their own fields. Through a comprehensive exploration of business practices, cultures, and the global economy, students will gain a robust foundation in the vocabulary and communication skills necessary for success in international business and cultural economics. This hands-on approach will provide tangible outcomes, preparing students for real-world professional scenarios. Course topics: International Markets, Real Estate, Business Management, Human Resources, International Cultural Economics & More.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as THEA 363 1) (The objective of this course is the development of linguistic and cultural understanding in the context of theatrical performance. The course is both critical and experiential. Through close readings of texts, script analysis, memorization, development of character, writing assignments, and theatrical performance, students will develop a deeper understanding of Spanish language and Hispanic cultures through the perspectives of both disciplines, Hispanism and Theater Studies. This critical/interpretive dimension will be enriched at all stages of the course by the experiential dimension: the physical and vocal embodiment/performance of the target language and texts. Course taught in Spanish. Texts: readings will be made available on Canvas. Particulars: Class exercises will involve physical and vocal warm-ups and improvisation; assignments, including writing essays and reading plays, will include individual activities as well as activities requiring outside class preparation with partners. Prerequisite: SPAN 212 Interested students must contact Prof. Elva Gonzalez at egonza3@emory.edu or Prof. Mary Lynn Owen at mowen3@emory.edu.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course applies concepts from medical humanities and community healthcare to the situation of Spanish speakers living in Georgia. Advancing in the line of SPAN 217R: Spanish for Health Care, students in this SPAN 385 continue to study grammar and vocabulary frequently used in interactions between healthcare professionals and patients. In addition, students will engage in and reflect on projects that advance the needs of organizations that serve Georgia Latino/Latinx communities. Recommended prerequisites: SPAN 217 (Spanish for Health Care) and one Foundational Spanish Course.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as LACS 409 1, LING 409 1, HLTH 469 1) This course examines how particular narratives about the body, health, and wellbeing are constructed and circulated in Latin America. Drawing on a number of classic and contemporary texts, we consider both the specificity of local medical narratives and the processes, which increasingly link these systems of knowledge and practice. The course queries how presupposed notions of language, communication, narrative, media, and the like provide implicit foundations for producing and naturalizing notions of health, disease, medicine, and the body and their associated practices and materialities. Topics covered include narrative production; local theories of disease causation and healing efficacy; narratives of embodiment; medicalization; structural violence; the meanings and effects of new medical technologies; and global health.) Texts: Provided by instructor. Prerequisites: At least one foundational course (SPAN 300- 318) or permission from instructor

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as LING 410 1) Title: Culture and the Senses: Embodied Experience Across Societies This course explores the intersection of sensory perception and cultural practices across different societies. Moving beyond the traditional Western emphasis on vision, we examine how diverse cultures engage with all five senses, sight, sound, taste, touch, and smell, and how these sensory experiences shape and are shaped by cultural frameworks. Students will investigate how sensory perception is culturally mediated, analyzing case studies that demonstrate how societies prioritize different senses and assign varying meanings to sensory experiences. From the acoustic landscapes of Warao ritual music in Venezuela, to the tactile significance of Guatemalan textile traditions, and from the olfactory coding in the Americas social interactions to the gustatory symbolism of Amazonian cooking practices, this course reveals how the senses function as both biological capabilities and cultural constructions. Through ethnographic readings, multimedia presentations, and experiential learning activities, students will develop theoretical frameworks for understanding sensory experience as a fundamental aspect of cultural identity and social organization. The course culminates in independent research projects examining how sensory practices reinforce or challenge cultural boundaries, social hierarchies, and embodied knowledge systems in diverse contexts around the world.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as LING 413W 1) DESCRIPTION: This course provides a descriptive and critical overview of the linguistic practices of different Spanish-speaking communities in the United States, as well as a methodology for the study of these practices. Students will learn about the linguistics characteristics of the different Spanish varieties spoken by these communities, including phonetic, morphological, syntactic and lexical aspects. Special attention is given to the relationship between language and society, particularly on topics such as ethnic and cultural identity, multilingualism and language policy. The course also presents a theoretical and practical approach to the ethnographic research method. Students will read and analyze studies carried out by different scholars and will design their own research project on the topic of their preference. Special attention is given to ethical principles, for this reason students will need to complete the web-based Collaborative IRB Training Initiative (CITI) Program in the Protection of Human Subjects in Research. Background on general Linguistics is recommended, such as the one provided in Span/Ling 303, Span/Ling 304 or Ling 201.This course meets the sociocultural requirement of the Linguistics Major and can be used as one of the required 400-level courses for the Joint Major in Spanish & Linguistics or for the Major/Minor in Spanish. TEXTS: - Escobar, Anna María and Kim Potowski. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. - Selection of articles available in Canvas. EVALUATION: Evaluation will be based in class participation, weekly assignments, one exam, one research project and five written practices. PRE-REQUISITES: One foundational course, preferably SPAN/LING 303 or SPAN/LING 304.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Content: Since the Enlightenment, the city has occupied a central position in Western culture, though the experience of urban life has changed with the evolution of the American and European city from modernity (the industrial city) to postmodernity (the global informational city). This course focuses on ways in which writers and artists express conflicting reactions to the city as a seductive and/or dangerous place to live, work and play, a place where people may interact via the shared culture of neighborhood communities or remain isolated by spatial segregation and the mobile nature of contemporary society. Centering on representations of Madrid, Barcelona, and New York sites of exchange and circulation among Spaniards, Latin Americans, and Latinxs we will ask: how are real cities imagined or remembered by those who live, visit, or immigrate there? How does the city map performances of social class, gender/sexuality, and ethnicity? Readings will draw from a variety of genres: memoirs, short stories, essays, poetry, film, theater, and websites. Texts: Sample texts/films and authors may include stories by Leopoldo Alas, Benito Pérez Galdós, Emilia Pardo Bazán, José Martí (Escenas neoyorquinas), Federico García Lorca (Poeta en Nueva York), Care Santos (Okupada), Pedro Pietri (Puerto Rican Obituary), Fernando Colomo (La línea del cielo), Pedro Almodóvar (Qué he hecho yo para merecer esto?), Quiara Alegría Hudes and Lin-Manuel Miranda (In the Heights), etc. Prerequisite: At least one 300-level foundational course for the Spanish Major or Minor OR one 400-level elective. Students wishing to enroll without these prerequisites should consult with the instructor, as there may be exceptions.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as PORT 485W 1) How did epics represent the Spanish and Portuguese imperial projects during the early modern period (1450-1800)? What are the cultural and literary marks that early modern epic poems have left on works from later periods? This course offers an in-depth discussion of a variety of literary genres from the Hispanic and Lusophone worlds through the prism of empire and coloniality. Students will first read early modern epics and think about how this genre was crucial in framing early modern colonial projects while also learning critical concepts and tools from literary studies, such as hero, protagonist, genre, character analysis, and formalism. Using the conceptual tools gained from discussing epic poems written in the Americas and the Iberian Peninsula, students will then reflect on works of later periods to examine the legacy of what was once one of the most popular literary genres, the epic. Throughout the semester, students will be invited to reflect on the differences between early modern and modern colonialism, the origins of modern racialized discourses, and the role of literature in framing the history of a nation. For their final projects, students are invited to either write about the 16th and 17th centuries, or think of a project on representations of imperial endeavors in the period and literary source of their choosing (including but not limited to poetry, novels, short stories, and cinema). Readings may include Lucan, Luis de Camões, Alonso de Ercilla, Miguel de Cervantes, Luis de Góngora, Sor Juana, Bento Teixeira, Juan de Miramontes. Taught in Spanish, with readings in Spanish (option for some readings in Portuguese available for majors and minors).

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as LACS 490R 1) Topic: Violence, Conflict, and National Reconciliation This course examines the most recent trends in contemporary Colombian cinema that have emerged in recent decades in the context of the negotiations and the signing of the Peace Accords (2012-2016). We will pay attention to the articulation of violence, conflict, and national reconciliation by studying the new forms of visual representation proposed by filmmakers such as William Vega, César Acevedo, Ciro Guerra, Cristina Gallego, Jorge Forero, and Laura Mora, among others. PREREQUISITES: At least one Foundational Course (SPAN 300-318W), or one 400-level Spanish course, or permission from the instructor.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 489RW 2, HLTH 485W 1, PORT 485W 1) Complete topic: The Public's Health in Latin America. What can the past teach us about the relationship between health equity and health access in Latin America. How does "Public Health" , as a profession and as an academic topic, connect to the public's health. This seminar focuses on how residents of Latin America understand health in their everyday lives. We will examine continuities and changes in approaches to healing, health, and disease over time by asking a series of related questions: How have patients and health professionals discussed disease, care, and cure? How have gender, ethnicity, citizenship status, and race shaped public health policies? In what ways did popular health practices figure into everyday life and national programs? How have global organizations engaged with everyday health through eradication and education programs? Students will investigate diverse actors through written, visual, and oral sources and will use primary documents and secondary material to analyze and construct arguments for their final research paper. Although our focus is on Latin America, the processes we will study were and are global in scope.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: CONTENT: Spanish 101 is a beginning-level integrated skills language course for students with no background in Spanish or only one year of high-school Spanish. The goals of this course include learning to use Spanish to communicate, learning of and about the tools of communication and studying Hispanic cultures to begin to understand how culture affects language use. Students participate in paired, small-group and whole-class conversation/listening activities that focus on meaningful communication and are required to do short readings and complete writing assignments. REQUIRED COURSE MATERIAL: Contraseña: Your Passport to Foundational Spanish (LingroLearning) + LinguaMeeting. Contraseña is a completely mobile and digital immersive experience, so there is no required printed textbook. Access is available for purchase directly from LingroLearning at www.lingrolearning.com PARTICULARS: Classes are conducted in Spanish to maximize exposure to the language. Evaluation is based on daily and active participation, online homework assignments, and portfolio projects. Friday classes will meet via Zoom for 50 minutes when there are no LinguaMeetings scheduled. PREREQUISITE: None, but students must take the Spanish Placement Exam and receive an Official Placement for SPAN 101 from the Department of Spanish and Portuguese. Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: SPAN 101 or SPAN_OX 101 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. This is an online course. Emory College Online summer courses have required synchronous/live sessions every week. Students must be available to sign into and virtually attend the course online during those times (noted as the course meeting times- all times listed are local to Atlanta). Each course will also involve significant asynchronous material that you access on your own time in addition to standard amounts of readings and course assignments. Students should plan to spend 15-20 hours/week on this course. Please also be aware that faculty will begin corresponding with students during Week Zero of the course (one week before the official start date of the course), and that some interaction with the course may be required at that time. Students should begin checking the Canvas course site regularly one week prior to the official start of the term. This course is a continuation of Spanish 101 and is an integrated-skills course designed to further promote basic communication in and with Hispanic communities and to heighten cultural awareness. The goals of this course include learning to use Spanish to communicate (through intensive interaction), primarily in speaking and listening, but also in reading and writing; learning of and about the tools of communication, including pronunciation, grammar and vocabulary; and continuing the study of Hispanic cultures to learn more about how culture affects language use. Students participate in paired, small-group and whole-class conversation/listening activities that focus on meaningful communication. Along with daily activities and readings, students will submit unit projects through Contraseña and take quizzes or submit discussions via Canvas. REQUIRED COURSE MATERIAL: Contraseña: Your Passport to Foundational Spanish (LingroLearning). Contraseña is a completely mobile and digital immersive experience, so there is no required printed textbook. Access is available for purchase directly from LingroLearning at www.lingrolearning.com PARTICULARS: Classes are conducted in Spanish to maximize exposure to the language. Evaluation is based on daily and active participation, online homework assignments, portfolio projects (Contraseña), and quizzes or discussions (Canvas). Please note that this course requires a significant amount of asynchronous work, in addition to the required synchronous sessions. PREREQUISITES: SPAN 101 or SPAN_OX 101. ****For enrollment, contact Sharlene Arruda Mendes at sharlene.arruda.mendes@emory.edu****

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Spanish 111 is an accelerated beginning-level language course designed to advance students towards a higher level of proficiency in both communication in the Spanish language and cultural knowledge of Hispanic communities. The course is intended for students with previous education in Spanish who need additional review and practice before advancing to the intermediate level. The goals of this course include the following: 1. Further improving communicative ability through speaking, listening, reading and writing skills; 2. Developing a more complex understanding of the tools of communication: basic linguistic units (words, idioms, verb forms, sounds) and grammar (rules which permit you to combine the units meaningfully); 3. Facilitating advancement from a primarily receptive to a productive use of the language; 4. Expanding cultural awareness, familiarity with and understanding of Hispanic cultures. and understanding of the relationship of culture to language. Prerequisite: Official Spanish Placement into Span 111 is required to remain in the course. (Take the Spanish placement exam online at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: CONTENT: This course, which is the first half of our intermediate sequence in Spanish and intended to be followed by Span 202, continues to develop students' communicative skills in Spanish and is designed for students who have fewer than four years formal experience studying Spanish and/ or who do not identify as heritage or native speakers of Spanish. While reviewing and acquiring new vocabulary, grammar, and pronunciation are central, learning about Hispanic/ Latino cultures is an integral part of the course as we will discuss our personal experiences and values, along with differences and changes among Spanish-speaking communities throughout the world. To this end, Span 201 aims to help students - continue to learn to use Spanish to communicate via active (speaking and writing) and passive modes (listening and reading); - further develop their knowledge of and about the tools of communication: basic linguistic units (words, idioms, conjugations, sounds) and grammar (rules which permit you to combine the units meaningfully); - explore, appreciate, and reflect upon a variety of Hispanic/ Latin/ Latinx cultures to critically discuss, compare, and analyze cultural productions. REQUIRED PROGRAM: Contraseña: Your Passport to Foundational Spanish (LingroLearning), a completely mobile and digital immersive experience. There is no required printed textbook. Purchase access to Contraseña directly from LingroLearning. PARTICULARS: Classes are conducted in Spanish, and daily attendance and active engagement are expected. EVALUATION is based on active participation and timely completion of homework, end-of-unit cumulative activities or quizzes, end-of-unit projects, and bi-weekly online meetings with coaches who are native speakers of Spanish. There is no final exam in SPAN 201. PREREQUISITES: SPAN 102, SPAN 111 or an Official Placement for SPAN 201 from the Department of Spanish and Portuguese. If you haven't done so already, be sure to take the required online Spanish Placement exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/exam.html well before fall semester starts.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: SPAN 201 or SPAN_OX 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. This is an online course. Emory College Online summer courses require weekly synchronous/live sessions. Students must be available to log in and attend these sessions virtually at the scheduled times (listed in Eastern Time, local to Atlanta). In addition to the live sessions, each course includes substantial asynchronous material, which students must engage with on their own time, along with regular readings and assignments. Students should expect to dedicate 15-20 hours per week to the course. Faculty will begin reaching out to students during Week Zero (one week before the official course start date), and some interaction with course content may be required at that time. Students should begin checking the Canvas course site regularly one week prior to the official start of the course. This course is a continuation of Spanish 201 and is designed to further develop students' Spanish skills. Students refine their grammar usage through continued review of basic structures and study of complex structures, and they expand their spoken Spanish skills through discussion and analysis of cultural topics, personal experiences, and literary and journalistic texts. Students are provided ample opportunity for focused listening through use of recorded texts (conversations, music, video) and for oral expression through general classroom and small-group discussions and oral reports. Readings in the course focus on both historical and current cultural and social issues in the Hispanic World. Writing is also developed as a communicative endeavor, with emphasis on the preparation of written compositions/reports based on the cultural components of the course. PREREQUISITE: SPAN 201 or SPAN_OX 201 ****For enrollment, contact Sharlene Arruda Mendes at sharlene.arruda.mendes@emory.edu****

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: CONTENT: This course focuses on developing both cultural understanding and linguistic skills. It explores cultural issues in the Hispanic world, such as diversity, gender roles and power structures through writing about and discussion of written texts and films. These texts also serve as the basis for practicing Spanish vocabulary and grammar in context, as well as honing listening, speaking, and particularly, reading and writing skills. By the end of the course, students should be able to use critical thinking skills in Spanish to interpret and discuss literature and film in Spanish, gain advanced proficiency in reading and writing the language, and gain knowledge of significant historical events. REQUIRED TEXT: Coutard, James, Evelyn, Katryn, Gaspar, Martin. Intrigas, 3rd ed. VHL, 2021. PARTICULARS: Movie screenings will be required outside of class. EVALUATION: Class participation, chapter quizzes, weekly homework, presentations, unit lesson essays. PREREQUISITE: SPAN 202 or Official Spanish Placement for SPAN 212. Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at https://spanport.emory.edu/undergraduate/placement/index.html SPAN 212 may be combined with a Spanish Foundational Course (300-318) or PORT 110 to satisfy both the HAL or Intercultural Communication requirement and major/minor requirements or electives. See https://spanport.emory.edu for details.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: CONTENT: Storytelling is universal; narratives are often thought of strictly as literature or art, but narrative is in fact something we engage in on a regular basis in all spheres of daily life. At the same time, narratives are situated in specific cultural contexts. This course will highlight Spanish-language literature and other forms of storytelling (film, visual and digital texts, journalism) from Spain, Latin America, and the U.S. that are expressions of citizen protest, analyzing how narrative genres and strategies are used to communicate these texts' messages to their audiences. Course texts are drawn from protests associated with environmental activism, indigenous movements, student movements, feminism and gender protests, critiques of economic neoliberalism, pro-democracy movements and defense of human rights. SPAN 311 is one of the foundational courses for the Spanish major and minor. PREREQUISITE: Spanish 212 or an official Spanish placement for a Foundational Course level (Span 300-318). Students wishing to enroll without this prerequisite should consult the instructor. Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html

requirement_sentence: (Same as SPAN 330 1) (The objective of this course is the development of linguistic and cultural understanding in the context of theatrical performance. The course is both critical and experiential. This critical/interpretive dimension will be enriched at all stages of the course by the experiential dimension: the physical and vocal embodiment/performance of the target language and texts. Course taught in Spanish. Texts: readings will be made available on Canvas. Particulars: Class exercises will involve physical and vocal warm-ups and improvisation; assignments, including writing essays and reading plays, will include individual activities as well as activities requiring outside class preparation with partners. title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ANT 377W 1) Pre-requisite: Previous sociocultural anthropology course at 200 level or above is required. This is a participatory course where students learn and practice creative forms of research-based theater making. Every day will be dynamic, in action, observing/documenting/exploring the human condition and humans' relations to lived environments and the natural world. Think: multisensorial qualitative research based seminar-lab-workshop-collaboratory! Students will learn how contemporary anthropologists are engaged in a range of theater making initiatives, forging new connections and engagements across techniques, traditions, and stakeholders. We will explore -- and practice -- the crafts of transitioning between ethnographic research, scriptwriting, acting, and staging. Our questions include: How does the ethnographer vividly convey the textures of life? How is analysis integrated with description? How are embodiment, affect, and multisensorial experiences documented ethnographically -- and conveyed through performance modalities? What are the ethical and moral responsibilities and implications of this kind of work? What are its political and liberatory potentialities? Students will develop skills through fieldwork exercises, movement techniques, theater games, and physical theater methods. Over the semester, students will produce ethnographic performances based on their own original research, and will present their projects in a semester-end showcase. No prior acting or performance experience is required.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: WGS 190 Feminist Film Theories: What makes a film theory a feminist one? What might feminism have to say about film theory? And where (and how) does the actual film (as image, text, object) stand in theory and feminism? With these questions as our preface, this course surveys a wide range of perspectives from different traditions and formations of feminism, film theory, as well as critical race theory, black studies/ black feminism, psychoanalysis, Marxism, and decolonial cinema. As one goal of the course, we will think through the tensions of these different disciplines and formations of thought to consider the space of difference. Rather than "applying theory" as a way to read images and the narrative arc of film, we will explore what this space of difference opens up in our texts and the films shown in class to consider how such a reorientation in reading might (re)shape our thinking (theories)of film and feminisms. The class will show films from the traditions of (not limited to): Third Cinema, the L.A. Rebellion, Kaidu Club (Korean feminist experimental films), Black British Cinema, and French New Wave.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: What is gender? identity? race? power? Why do any of these concepts matter to feminist thinking? Through weekly readings and discussion, this course will survey live debates at the heart of the interdisciplinary project of Women's, Gender, & Sexuality Studies. Students will develop an understanding of key approaches within the field such as feminist utopias, intersectionality, affect, transnational feminisms, queer theory, and racial capitalism. We will develop a reading practice to approach a variety of genres (academic articles, short stories, poetry, music videos). Students are expected to complete assigned readings in advance of every class meeting and practice the skill of participation by sharing their questions and insights. Assignments will include weekly journal responses, a midterm, and a final project. No prior knowledge of the field is required.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (This course is an introduction to the interdisciplinary field of sexuality studies. It will explore the diversity of contemporary sexual experience, sexual behavior and sexual identity, and put into question what we take to be natural, normal or liberatory about these experiences, behaviors and identities. This exploration will be guided by two key theorists of sexuality: Sigmund Freud and Michel Foucault. How does sexuality emerge in the infant? What is the relation between the normal and the perverse? What is the relation between sexuality and power? Beginning with pre-Stonewall homophile politics in the US and moving through the radical era of the 1970s, the course will investigate the foundations of current queer studies and activism. In the last part of the course, we will consider three key contemporary debates in sexuality: adolescence; pornography; queer comics.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (This course is an introduction to the histories, questions, and concepts in the interdisciplinary field of Trans Studies. How has the relatively recent emergence of "transgender" as a term shaped thought around gender, sex, and race? How is Trans Studies entangled with feminism and Queer Studies? How has cultural production shaped thought in Trans Studies? We will read with and against inherited frameworks to better understand and respond to historical and contemporary debates in the field. We will look at theoretical texts alongside various cultural objects such as art, movies, literature, and music videos, always with an attention to our current moment. In tending the field, our goal is to develop practices of reading and critical thinking that encourage creative leaps and a careful skepticism toward ideas that pass themselves off as common sense. This is an interdisciplinary, discussion-based course designed for students across the University, including those in the arts and humanities, as well as social and natural sciences.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ANT 265 1) (This course provides cultural anthropological perspectives on gender and sexual diversity in a broad range of human societies, emphasizing ethnographic and theoretical works that deal with gender and sexuality as culturally constructed, historically variable, and politically contested categories bearing on practice and desire, rather than immutable biological "givens." One of the primary objectives of the course is to develop an understanding of the enormous range of variation in human societies regarding gender roles and the constructions and entailments of femininity, masculinity, heteronormativity, gender variance, and same-sex erotics, particularly in relation to axes of difference and inequality associated with race, class, and religion. We begin with early anthropological debates (from the 1970s) on "the status of women" , the prevalence of male dominance, and the ways scholars involved in these debates drew upon 19th- and early 20th-century theorists (e.g., Marx, Engels, Freud, and Levi-Strauss) to frame both their research questions and their contributions to these debates. We will continue with psychoanalytic approaches to cultures of masculinity and sexuality; queer feminist understandings of heteronormativity, same-sex sexuality and gender variance both, at home, and transnationally; and the contributions of Black feminist anthropology and intersectional perspectives on race, class, gender, and sexuality.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as EAS 285W 1) Asian American Feminisms: This course will examine Asian Americanist approaches to studies of gender and sexuality. Key topics include negotiating familial gender roles and varieties of "coming out;" sexualization and desexualization in media; feminist disability politics (with starting points in Mimi Khúc's Dear Elia and Johanna Hedva's "Sick Woman Theory"); feminist, queer, and trans self-representations in popular and grassroots genres; and reimaginings of kinship beyond normative family structures. In addition to academic texts, our sources will include memoir, performance (comedy, drag, spoken word, TV), and fiction. Our analysis will emphasize feminist approaches to historical and contemporary modes of imperialism, exclusion, and exotification that mobilize skin color, citizenship, geopolitics, religion, and class in order to understand uneven conditions across Asian diasporas. We will also engage with Pacific Islander scholars and cultural workers to question what effects groupings like "AAPI," "APA," and "APIDA" have on attempts at queer and feminist solidarity.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as EAS 285W 1) Asian American Feminisms: This course will examine Asian Americanist approaches to studies of gender and sexuality. In addition to academic texts, our sources will include memoir, performance (comedy, drag, spoken word, TV), and fiction. title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Feminist Theory (WGS 300) delves deeply into the foundational and vibrantly contested debates that define the field of feminist theory. Students will become familiar with a variety of theoretical perspectives, including those influenced by queer theory, trans studies, Black feminism, transnational feminism, radical feminism, post-structuralist feminism, psychoanalysis, and more. In doing so, students will develop an understanding of the disjunctures and disagreements that have propelled feminist theory forward, making it both a dynamic field of scholarly research and an indispensable analytic that guides feminist politics. In addition to gaining a deeper understanding of feminist theory, students will also hone their analytic skillset by evaluating, interpreting, and elaborating on said theories, as well as applying those theories to current feminist debates, in the form of written assignments and engaged class discussion.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as AFS 345 1) In this course, we will examine feminist activism to bring justice to survivors of sexual violence in peacetime and in conflict. We will examine theories of sexual violence, trauma, and memory as we seek to understand what justice for survivors might look like. Topics will include sexual violence in apartheid and post-apartheid South Africa; the Rwandan Genocide and more contemporary examples including Ukraine. We will learn about and assess the efforts to try and bring resolution to these divided societies. Students' research papers may be on any topic related to sexual violence and justice.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as POLS 357 1) This course is designed to introduce students to the study of gender and U.S. politics. Readings and class discussion will concentrate on four general themes: (1) the role of gender in defining and shaping politics, political institutions, political behavior and public policy; (2) the various ways in which women, as political actors and theorists, have challenged and redefined "politics as usual"; (3) the question of whether women are a political (interest) group; and (4) the relationships between gender and other axes of identity, such as class, race, ethnicity, and sexuality. Thus, we will study gender both as a political construct or ideology and as a system of political (economic and social) stratification. In addition, we will examine how these aspects of gender affect the political behavior and experiences of individuals as citizens, voters, political leaders, political candidates, and public officials. Similar questions and themes regarding sexuality and LGBTQ+ individuals in politics will also be explored.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: The Sexual Politics of Empire with Dr. Matthew Chin: Drawing on Queer Studies and Studies of Empire this course analyzes how sexuality operates as a key terrain on which struggles over colonial power unfold. It pays special attention to the history and political economy of sexual empires and the ways that race and gender shape sexual life under colonialism. It also takes seriously projects of decolonization and asks students to consider why and how sexuality matters to these projects. This course addresses three main areas of inquiry: Why do empires care about sex? How do our sexual lives carry the imprint of imperial power? And what does it mean to decolonize sex?

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 370W 1) Queerness and Religion: Queerness is often positioned in intuitive opposition to "religion." Without assuming necessary antagonism, we will consider how queer religious subjects navigate identity, embodiment, and gender and sexuality's relationships to other forms of social difference. This course will situate queer religious subjectivities in wider fields of debate about the power relations that shape normative understandings of religion, gender, and sexuality, including contestations over whose voices are trustworthy and authoritative. We will consider collective and ecstatic experiences in ritual, mysticism, community formation, and spirit possession and ask what kinds of queer knowledge these contexts might reflect and generate. Course readings will take theoretical, theological, anthropological, and creative approaches to questions like: How do religious commitments shape queer relational and sexual ethics? How does devotion to divinities and spirits relate to love between humans? Are queer ways of being somehow religious or spiritual even when they do not identify with a particular tradition? Is "queerness" in religion primarily a mode of interpreting sacred texts, a matter of practitioners' sexual orientations, an approach to collectivity, or something else entirely?

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as POLS 285 1) (This course examines the political, racial, and economic evolution of American cities and towns in the post-Civil Rights Movement era. The first half of the course focuses on dominant themes in political economy, political geography, and political behavior literature. The intersection of race and class at the local level is addressed, while exploring issues of institutional discrimination and redistribution. The second part of the course, applies learned concepts and ideas to 4 case studies: de-industrialization in Chicago, the rural healthcare crisis in Mississippi, rapid population change in Atlanta, and public education funding in Los Angeles. Students will gain an understanding of how the local political economy shapes opportunity, mobility, and racial relations in America.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 270 7, AFS 270 4) Complete Topic: Our Gods Never Left: Introduction to African & African Diaspora Studies This course examines African religions such as Nigerian Ifá-Òrìsà tradition, Congolese religions, indigenized Christianity and Islam as well as African Diaspora religions of Haitian Vodou, Cuban Lucumí and Palo, Jamaican Rastafari, and Black American Hoodoo and Conjure traditions. Employing a comparative religion approach, we explore Black Atlantic religious themes such as: God(s), spirit, and ancestor veneration, divination and sacred space, initiation and sacred arts, healing and the environment, gender and power, the impact of slavery on conversion/continuity, migration and diaspora. Ultimately, this introductory course encourages students to reevaluate their understanding of Africana religions as they gain familiarity with diverse cultural philosophies and ritual knowledge systems of these valuable ancestral traditions.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as MUS 303 1) Music and Performance in the African Diaspora is an interdisciplinary course exploring critical perspectives on Black music, dance, and culture in the US and abroad. We will build a critique of cultural production emphasizing an intersectional framework and critique of oppression via black studies, black feminisms, and sound studies. This class will bring together various media, social science, film, and art as we discuss legacies of blues, jazz, funk, hip hop, and techno. We will work toward a broad definition of black music to consider its history and global circulation.

requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 378 1, ANT 378 1, LACS 378 1) The course explores human trafficking from the era of the trans- Atlantic slave trade to present-day instances of trafficking in productive and reproductive labor. Through primary and secondary sources, the students learn about the racial and gender ideologies undergirding this phenomenon.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ARTHIST 365 1) "POSTCOLONIAL ARTS OF AFRICA"Artists linked to the continent of Africa at times resist framing their work according to ethnic, national, or continental identities. Yet complex histories and understandings of identity often contribute to the content or reception of the artists' work. What expectations might visitors to American or European museums and galleries have about art by an artist specifically identified with the continent of Africa? And how might expectations change if the art were not presented with a qualifier that linked the artist or the work to the continent? Answers to such questions impact where in a museum we might find an artist's work and how a museum might present the work. The course requires no previous study of the continent of Africa or African art. We will focus on arts created for worldwide audiences by diverse artists linked to different areas of the African continent. We will look at, read about, discuss, write about, and otherwise reflect upon a range of works in order to think about what various labels reveal and conceal about art, identity, and experience in national and transnational contexts. Art History major/minors: Div III or IV

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ENG 345W 1) Topic: Writing Independence in and beyond Africa In this course we will explore some of the most powerful literary works produced by African writers since the start of decolonization in the 1950s. How do African writers imagine cultural, political, and personal independence? How have experiences of migration and of dissident sexuality inspired new kinds of literature? What kinds of freedom are at stake in these texts? Focusing on English-language fiction, this course will introduce the work of novelists Chinua Achebe, Bessie Head, and Jennifer Nansubuga Makumbi. We will also encounter multilingual worlds through the poetry of Safia Elhillo and Romeo Oriogun, as well as at least one classic and one contemporary film. We will have a chance to engage with an exhibition of contemporary African art at the Carlos Museum and to meet Oriogun, winner of the Nigeria Prize for Literature, when he visits Emory in October. Assessments will include weekly reading responses, two individual conferences, a literary analysis, a scholarly annotation, and a creative project but no research paper. In other words, we will meet the Continuing Communication requirement through frequent shorter compositions rather than a long high-stakes essay. GER tags: ETHN and HAPW | Eng. Major Requirement(s): 20th-21st Centuries; Diverse Perspectives I&II

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course begins with a broad exploration of traditional Medical Anthropology topics. What is disease/illness? Who facilitates health and wellness professionally or ritualistically, and how? After examining the concepts of illness and disease in cross-cultural and historical contexts, the course will focus on emergent biomedical practices. We will explore both their strengths and shortcomings and how they are being complemented/supplemented. We will also focus on medical/wellness discourse in Atlanta, and Emory in particular, and our unique role in both local and global health outcomes.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as WGS 333 1 and LING 333 1) Although we are surrounded by messages about gender and sexuality from an early age, what agency do we have in creating and displaying gender and sexuality and what role does language play in this process? What do terms like transgender, cisgender, non-binary, and genderqueer mean and why does gender-inclusive and gender-affirming language matter? How do other elements of our social identities (i.e. race, class, nationality, etc.) intersect with language, gender, and sexuality? As we search for answers to these questions, we will explore sociolinguistic, anthropological, and feminist approaches to the study of language, gender, and sexuality. We will examine our assumptions and beliefs about gender and sexuality and the ways that our beliefs are encoded in the language that we use. We will also explore how and why people display different ways of speaking based on their gender and sexual identities.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 378 1, AFS 378 1, LACS 378 1) The course explores human trafficking from the era of the trans- Atlantic slave trade to present-day instances of trafficking in productive and reproductive labor. Through primary and secondary sources, the students learn about the racial and gender ideologies undergirding this phenomenon.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as MUS 370W 2) (This course explores how the practice of Indigenized religious songs represents Indigenous ontologies, promotes processes of Indigenous language revitalization, and serves a common understanding that Indigenous communities are interconnected. This course views the practices of translating and transforming hymns as contributions to claims of Indigenous cultural sovereignty and the maintenance of Indigenous identity. This course practices Indigenous relational accountability by teaching students to understand what has happened in the past and how the past continues to be felt in the present and how it structures the present, including histories of forced education and forced participation in religious activities. This course analyzes many forms of knowledge and knowledge transmission, including oral, written, embodied, artistic, environmental, and geographic relations. This course encourages students to reflect upon their positions and relationships in their own communities and in relation to Indigenous communities. The ability to read traditional music notation can be helpful but not required to take this course.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as WGS 385 8) This course introduces students to the cultural and political dimensions of law, discipline, and social justice in a wide array of human societies. Readings and discussions provide anthropological and historical perspectives on the ways people organize and experience different types of justice, power, discipline, policing, state violence, and institutionalized racism and heterosexism in the context of neoliberal globalization. In exploring these topics, we will draw upon feminist scholarship, critical legal studies, and theoretical perspectives associated with Marx and Foucault. With respect to case studies and areal focus, some of the initial readings deal with the U.S. colonization of Hawai'i; most of the rest of course focuses on the West (especially the U.S. and France) and the Muslim world (particularly Malaysia).

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: All across the globe democracy is in crisis. The rise of authoritarianism, fascism, militarism, fundamentalism, communalism, racial intolerance, indifference to the rule of law, and a host of other social forces seem to threaten democracy at its very core, in ways that are wholly unprecedented. In this course we explore competing explanations regarding why democracy is in crisis. We also focus on the moral panic that is unfolding around the current crisis, and we investigate what people mean when they say democracy is under threat. We do so by examining a broad range of contexts from around the world in which democracy has been called into question. We also explore the increasingly common perception that we are entering a "post-democratic age."

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as WGS 265 1) (This course provides cultural anthropological perspectives on gender and sexual diversity in a broad range of human societies, emphasizing ethnographic and theoretical works that deal with gender and sexuality as culturally constructed, historically variable, and politically contested categories bearing on practice and desire, rather than immutable biological "givens." One of the primary objectives of the course is to develop an understanding of the enormous range of variation in human societies regarding gender roles and the constructions and entailments of femininity, masculinity, heteronormativity, gender variance, and same-sex erotics, particularly in relation to axes of difference and inequality associated with race, class, and religion. We begin with early anthropological debates (from the 1970s) on "the status of women" , the prevalence of male dominance, and the ways scholars involved in these debates drew upon 19th- and early 20th-century theorists (e.g., Marx, Engels, Freud, and Levi-Strauss) to frame both their research questions and their contributions to these debates. We will continue with psychoanalytic approaches to cultures of masculinity and sexuality; queer feminist understandings of heteronormativity, same-sex sexuality and gender variance both, at home, and transnationally; and the contributions of Black feminist anthropology and intersectional perspectives on race, class, gender, and sexuality.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: ARAB_OX 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.
